Ulasan:
A quick bit of info. Between my wife and I we are currently using a Galaxy s8 and now this Huawei Mate se. We have been using the mate se for about 3 weeks now and feel confident in reviewing it.

For starters like a lot of Americans we were not familiar with the Huawei brand when we went to purchase a new phone to replace an older model phone. We spent the better part of three days comparing various phones from a variety of makers with the phones we knew best Samsung Galaxy series. After reading many reviews both on seller sites and in tech magazines we decided that for what they were selling for on amazon ($249.99) if the Huawei Mate se was as good as we were reading we couldn't go wrong

The phone we ordered was from a third party seller and they deserve some credit here after being quoted an arrival window of eight to ten days they got it to us in only four. So to bayshine store kudos to you on that one.

Just out the box the phone looked good reminiscent more of iPhones then Galaxies in my opinion,either way startup and set up were a breeze.

Now down to the brass tacks we have run several comparisons between this phone and our Samsung and honestly and I mean no disrespect to Samsung here this phone is almost on par with it. The few bells and whistles that this phone lacks are just that only bells and whistles. Just to point out some of our tests.
Browsing the internet

Playing games
Listening to music
Battery life
Watching videos
Camera Picture quality
Camera Video quality

Our results are surprising. In all of the categories except for camera picture/video quality the difference between them is almost moot the Samsung charges faster and has better low light picture and video capabilities.

The only complaints I have about the mate se is regarding such trivial things as downloading themes and backgrounds. Stuff of that nature. We found that we were unable to send gifs over mms when using the primary texting software and we had to get the messenger app from the app store. These are all small little nuisance issues and easy to adapt to especially considering the Huawei costs almost a third of what we paid for the s8 when we got it.

Now we don't feel confident to sit her and discuss the nuances of the specifications regarding this product but from a casual users perspective we could not be happier with Huawei's mate se phone. It is everything we need in a phone for an amazing price.

I would and do recommend this product to anyone looking to purchase a great phone.

If you find this review helpful please let us know. If you have any questions we would be happy to answer.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
Well, I am a very experienced Techie type and I was looking on Amazon for a 64 GB Internal storage with 256GB external SD Card Capabilities and close to 6 inch Android Unlocked Phone. Before I purchased this phone (in the Gold color), I read all the specs and made sure it would work with my AT&T LTE Data plan, Texting, Phone calls and also my home WiFi. And It works fine for my WiFi and Data needs.

*My goal in this review is to help you with your decision of whether or not to purchase this phone. Please note that this review reflects my personal opinions and experience with this phone.*

PROS:

1) 64GB of Internal Storage...however after the OS and Factory Apps, it had 51gb left. After I installed lots of personal Apps such as Word and Excel (free from Playstore) and several weather apps, Facebook, Twitter and Kindle, I have 46.84gb left. Plenty left if I want to install more apps or updates on apps.

2) 4G/LTE Data/Hot Spot Info. I have a ATT Data plan so I tested for 4G/LTE on an app and it verified that I have 4G/LTE. My LTE data is very fast and works perfectly when I out of a WI-FI area. The data hotspot worked great as I tested this on other devices.

3) Android OS---My phone arrived with Oreo 8.0 pre-installed. And it runs flawlessly!

4) WiFi and Bluetooth abilities: My WiFi Router is a ATT UVERSE 2Wire model (not a 5 Ghz). The WiFi connected immediately to this phone and it is a very fast WiFi, I tested the speed of the WiFi using an app WiFi Analyzer Pro, it tested at 72 mbps. So I am very pleased with this. Also, the WiFi is super strong and I receive 5 bars around my home and it keeps the strong connection even in my backyard.
* Bluetooth...So I setup a Bluetooth speaker and Bluetooth headset, both connected wonderfully to this phone.
I kept the Bluetooth speaker on and played music while WiFi was connected. Both did fine and my WiFi worked well and had a very strong signal.*
***If you later on buy a 5GHZ Router, make sure that is DUAL BAND and auto switchable to 2.4GHZ. Some of the higher end Routers have dual band/switchable 5GHZ/2.4GHZ. The newer, high end Routers auto switch ( make sure it is setup for this). This way it allow the 2.4GHZ Devices to connect to 2.4 GHZ band and the newer 5 GHZ devices can connect to the the 5 GHZ band. I have researched 5 GHZ/2.4 GHZ Routers thoroughly as I hope to purchase a new Dual band 2.4 GHZ/5 GHZ Router in a few months..this way, I can connect any device to the WIFI. However, right now my 2.4 GHZ AT&T Uverse Router is fast and my phone gets 4 bars of WIFI even in my large backyard, 2.4 GHZ band has a longer distance than the 5GHZ band. I prefer the 2.4 GHZ band over the 5 GHZ band because I need a longer distance because I am in a large house and need to connect to WIFI in any room I want to, even outside in my yard). And the 2.4 GHZ connects well with a great speed.

5) Display---The almost 6 inch (5.93 inch) display is very, very clear and colors vivid as it has 407 PPI sharpness, super sharp and the colors are vibrant! Reading on the Internet, Kindle book or PDF Book, the text is very crisp. The videos in YouTube are very clear as well.

6) Speed and Performance--I use Word, Excel, Facebook, Twitter, Internet, YouTube, Email, etc. I do not play games on this phone yet I found all videos run very well.
Performs well, no lagging and no freezing.

7) WiFi calling---Huawei does NOT have ACTUAL WIFI CALLING on this phone. I have a Google Hangouts account and Google assigned me a number. For me to call on WiFi, I use my GOOGLE VOICE PHONE NUMBER, which is different from my cellphone SIM CARD number. Note that I use Google Hangouts on my non cellular Tablet sometimes to make a "WiFi" phone call.

8) External Slot for SD Card---So I installed a SanDisk 128gb Micro SD card which was loaded with my music, pictures, home videos and files. I still have 75 gb left on my SD Card. According to Gsmarena, this device holds up to 256 GB Micro SD card.

9) Camera---I actually took some inside and outside pictures and saved them to my SD Card. The pictures (indoors and outdoors) are very clear, excellent for sending in email or even Facebook. My videos also came out well.

10) Battery life and Device Coolness---Battery life I find excellent and I am a heavy user of apps. I watch lots of YouTube videos, Facebook, listen to my music etc. My battery starts off at 100 percent, then after one hour of heavy use it shows close to 90 percent. So I am pleased.
***Device coolness/Battery coolness---The battery temp is usually at 77F to 86F, but after downloading say several books on my Kindle app, it will reach 95F, then go right back down to 86F. I use Battery Solo Widget free from the Playstore.

11) Printing documents on this phone. So I installed PrinterShare app from Playstore. Using the SHARE option in Word, Excel and many other apps, I print right from this phone as it prints on my HP Wireless printer. No need to get on my laptop to print!

12) Sound Clarity: I use 2 types of headsets, the wired type and the Bluetooth type. When I use a wired headset, it has good quality. And when I use my older Bluetooth headset it als o sounds great. Personally, I find the sound on this phone using a headset or Bluetooth speakers is excellent. And I listen to music, videos often with this phone. Also the phone call clarity is excellent as well, both on SPEAKERPHONE or using the phone by my ear.

13) USB Port is MICRO not a type C. However it does have OTG (On the Go), which means with a USB/Micro adapter, you can insert a USB Flash drive, USB mouse, keyboard (one at a time). I use this to copy files from my Flash drive to my phone or vice versa).

Cons...Three cons:
1) USB Port is MICRO not a type C. However, I was happy because I have several MICRO chargers. No need to buy a new Type C one as my spare charger.
2) NO 5GHZ WiFi receiver. Since I have an older router without 5ghz, this is not a problem for me. *If you have a 5ghz router, you may want to consider another phone that has 5ghz capabilities.
3) NO NFC...This I was aware of and I do not use this feature anyway. If you need to use NFC, then this phone would NOT be the best choice for you.

Note that I am rating this 4.5 stars, rounded off to 5 stars because this phone has 64gb internal, huge screen with superb clarity and this a beautiful phone that is reasonably priced, yet looks expensive.

Would I buy this phone again? Yes, because of the very large screen, 64gb internal space and great price.
***Thank you for reading my review. I hope that it has helped you in your decision of whether or not to purchase this phone.***
Since I am a techie type, ask me questions if you like.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
bought the GOLD version of this Huawei Mate SE for $229 + sales tax from here on amazon. as an iPhone person who recently turned to Huawei, this is a fabulous great phone from Huawei. my iPhone was flaking out because of apple's horrible battery shutdown/slowdown problems. apple jumped the shark trying to fool people about what was really happening with iPhone batteries. anyways, previously got a nice AT&T-branded Huawei Ascend XT2 which was like my training-wheels version to get me ready for this much more powerful unlocked Huawei Mate SE. Huawei got me hooked with its EMUI 5.1 (based on Android 7.0) that is designed to kinda be reminiscent of the iPhone iOS, particularly when you turn off the app drawer, but still a powerful android. so switching to the new Huawei Mate SE was easy peasy. and having 4GB RAM and 64GB storage really helped a lot to make the phone much more comfortable to use without worrying about lack of memory or lack of space. oh, in comparison, looking at the Huawei Honor 7x here on amazon, but for a little bit more in price, the Huawei Mate SE is the definite better buy. both the Huawei Honor 7x and the Huawei Mate SE look the same but the major difference is the Huawei Mate SE is more powerful with the 4GB RAM and 64GB storage. and the Huawei Mate SE is available in a GOLD version. my preferred phone gold color version. yea! definite no brainer. got the Huawei Mate SE.

myself originally coming from iPhone, my suggestion to others regarding apps to make the transition in finding very good equivalent apps to iPhone's iMessages, Find My iPhone, and Find My Friends, is to go to the Google Play Store to download WhatsApp, Find My Device (from google), and Family Locator GPS Tracker (from Life360). and if you are like me thinking the android app drawer is a bit bothersome, well, you can turn it off in the settings on this Huawei phone. hopefully this advice should get you started if you want to have a more iphone-like experience on a Huawei phone.

my journey is complete moving from iPhone to android where this Huawei Mate SE has become my primary phone. using this phone on AT&T and have 4G LTE. the Wi-Fi is only regular 2.5GHz wifi -- without the 5GHz wifi option (the Huawei Ascend XT2 has both 2.5GHz wifi and 5GHz wifi) but that's just fine if all your WiFi access is mostly to regular 2.5GHz wifi wherever you go and wherever you happen to be. personally still carry an iPhone as a backup phone in my go bag, but this Huawei Mate SE is my main phone now. went through other android phones, then recently got the aforementioned Huawei Ascend XT2, and now have this absolutely beautiful gorgeous Huawei Mate SE. physically very iphone-like and almost similar to the iPhone 7+ with the metal body plus with the dual camera on the back in the top corner like on the iPhone 8+ and then with the more modern 18:9 size front screen like on the iPhone X but without the iPhoneX ugly notch. also this Huawei Mate SE has a real must-have earphone jack. and this absolutely beautiful powerful phone performs smoothly with no lag. and Huawei seems to be hinting that Android 8 and most likely a newer EMUI are on the way for this and other Huawei phones for sometime during March 2018 or whenever. [edit: Honor 7x beta testing Android 8 and EMUI 8 began March 15. with maybe possible full release in April? (because news also reports Honor India says April for official release.) Huawei Mate SE should presumedly also get the android8 upgrade in the same timeframe sometime soonish whenever thereabouts is my guess....] so this phone will get even better with huawei support. yes, this Huawei Mate SE is very satisfactory. very happy with this phone.

PS: people have commented in other reviews that if you turn on bluetooth, then the Wi-Fi slows down. this has particularly been reported in amazon reviews for the Honor 7x, and at least one other person mentioned it in a review here for the Huawei Mate SE. so, did a speed test to see what happens with my Huawei Mate SE on my home wifi internet: (1) wifi + no bluetooth had 47Mbps wifi internet speed; but (2) wifi + bluetooth turned on had 31Mbps wifi internet speed. this was tested using the Fast dot com website (which is reportedly owned by Netflix). okay this is with an ARRIS TG2472G cable modem with built-in WiFi that can handle both 2.5GHz and 5GHz, but only 2.5GHz is relevant for the Huawei Mate SE, where my home internet is on the Cox Internet Preferred 100 Plan, and so my plan's internet speed can be as high as 100Mbps on the 5GHz side but typically half that on the 2.5GHz side. of course, we are only concerned with the 2.5GHz wifi. turning on bluetooth and getting 30+ Mbps wifi internet speed doesn't matter in a noticeable way to me on my home internet plan. however, if your home internet is much slower like on a basic starter plan with a maximum speed of 10Mbps or less, then proportionally any decreased wifi speed with bluetooth turned on could possibly be noticeable to you. sorry, if you are a big bluetooth user. me not use an android gear watch or bluetooth earphones. if you really don't use bluetooth, then keep the BT off and this issue won't matter to you when you are on wifi. but if you are out away from home trying to use free wifi which can be congested or which may have throttled speeds already, then this BT issue could affect you -- and so maybe just use cellular data in that situation if you really need your BT. personally, this BT issue is not a deal killer for me. this is a great phone imho.

PSS: okay maybe the bluetooth-wifi issue is a load of hooey. tried testing wifi internet speed with the bluetooth turned on while on the Wi-Fi at my parents' home where they have a DLink 2.5GHz wifi router and where my folks are on the Cox basic starter internet plan that has an advertised max speed of 10Mbps: (1) wifi + no bluetooth had wifi internet speeds of 9.8Mbps and 11Mbps; but (2) wifi + bluetooth turned on had wifi internet speeds of 8.4Mbps and 10Mbps. this was tested using the Fast dot com website (which is owned by Netflix). it's like no difference whether bluetooth is turn on or off as to the effect on wifi. but other real life factors could be involved -- that's for any picky bluetooth users to test, such as also using their particular bluetooth devices, because at this point, this so-called bluetooth-wifi issue is a non-issue for me. but my guess is if there is any effect, then it's a combination of your wifi router and/or your bluetooth device(s). (yeah, have previously seen differences in using a bluetooth speaker on my macbook versus on my iphone.) in other words, YMMV. bottomline as far as the Huawei Mate SE goes, get the phone, and if you are like me then you'll most likely love the phone.

Another PS: (03/29/2018) just got the latest android security patch dated March 1, 2018 for the android 7 on this Huawei Mate SE. this is update version B130. it's not android 8 yet. comments elsewhere over on the xda-developer forum indicate that testing for android 8 (and also presumedly emui 8) on Huawei Mate SE may occur after testing is finished for the Honor7x. my guess at this point is to expect beta testing in April(?) or May(?) with official final distribution sometime soonish afterwards?? just have to wait and see. okay yeah would love to right now have android 8 (with treble to allow for more timely updates?), but this Huawei Mate SE, with android 7.0 and EMUI 5.1, plus with the latest android security update, is a very good reasonably up-to-date secure phone. my bottomline recommendation still stands to say this Huawei Mate SE is definitely a great phone very much worth getting.

Yet Another PS (04/17/2018): GSMARENA indicates that Huawei Honor 7x to get EMUI 8, based on Android 8, to officially roll out with final release in May 2018. so maybe beta testing of Android 8 & EMUI 8 for Huawei Mate SE will occur sometime thereafter? could be looking at June/July for official final release on Huawei Mate SE is my current guess?? we'll see.... meanwhile, me currently still very happy with my Huawei Mate SE. oh, an app tip for those who use their Huawei Mate SE in the car: if you need a car app for playing your music and handling your calls & texts while driving, myself using the DRIVEMODE free app (found in the google play store). imho, it's better than Android Auto. can activate & turn off Drivemode from notifications, and overlay Drivemode on top of the music app, plus easy swipes & taps to control my tunes, and big buttons for answering calls & texts as well as voice control to answer calls and to read/answer texts. (oh, with the overlay, you may want to fully increase screen brightness & turn off the eye comfort.) drivemode works great with my whatsapp also. and particularly, the bigger controls (swipe or tap anywhere on the screen) makes it easy to manage my music tunes while driving, kinda sorta like on my old iphone, but different & better on my Huawei Mate SE which is usually docked on the dashboard of my car when me out driving. hope you all are enjoying your Huawei Mate SE (or soon will be if you are looking to get one).

Still Yet Another PS (05/09/2018): there are discussion messages over on XDA-Developers that indicate an Over-The-Air update to Android 8.0 is being pushed out in batches to Huawei Mate SE. the batches are apparently randomly sent out and so you may not get it right away. still hasn't shown up on mine yet. sounds like minor changes, but have to wait to see. good luck and enjoy your Huawei Mate SE.

PS Update (May 11, 2018): finally got the Android 8.0 & EMUI 8.0 update. see attached picture. if you have a Huawei Mate SE, you should also be getting this update. yes, this is the phone worth getting. Thanks, Huawei! ADDENDUM: after updating to Android 8.0 (EMUI 8.0), some apps like Swarm, Yelp, weather apps, etc may not show maps inside those apps and may instead state an error message stuck on saying: Google Play Services are updating. you have to clear the data for Google Play Services in the settings app. Settings > Google > Location > Google Play services > Storage > and then clear both Cache (Clear Cache) and Data (Manage Data > Clear All Data) -- and that should fix the maps inside apps.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
Nothing even close to the overall quality, performance and features at this price point that I have found. Many people have written extensively about the features and pros/cons, so I'll just summarize my review with ratings based on what I think is a value at this price, with 10 being best value around. I don't have an iPhone 8 or X or Google Pixel to compare it to, but I do have an iPhone 6. These are my ratings after about 1 month of steady use:

Display: 8 - Not as good as the retina display, some barely visible pixellation on text, but images look great. Viewing at angle reveals limitations. The large size and small bezel make up for it.
Sound: 8 - Good quality for music, headphone output is detailed and powerful. Just a hint of hissiness on calls. Speakers are just OK.
Speed: 10 - The only thing that slows it down is resource intensive video games. Opening apps, running tasks are all lightning fast.
Build Quality: 10 - At least from the outside. Looks and feels very solid and well made. Buttons are responsive, connectors are solid.
Weight: 8 - It is a bit heavy for a phone of this size, but that seems to reflect the build quality rather than clunkiness.
Stability: 10 - No issues so far - I carry it around everywhere, no random sluggishness, no app freezes, etc. Boots up very fast.
Interface/GUI: 9 - The EMUI is good enough for what I need and I've arranged my apps for quick access.
Battery: 10 - This is where this phone really shines - I could probably go 3 days without charging under normal use, but I'm not a heavy user.
Bloat: 9 - There's not much extra stuff loaded and what is there can be turned off or ignored and doesn't seem to drain resources.
Fingerprint Sensor: 10 - If I could give this an 11 I would. I never thought a fingerprint sensor could add so much convenience but now I am spoiled. It makes the iPhone 6 sensor seem sluggish.
Camera: 9 - The resolution is very high, but the photos are just OK. Better than most phones at this price. Images tend to be somewhat grainy when zoomed. Seems that Huawei decided to go for max detail at the cost of a slight harshness to images. Camera is not very good in low light.
Memory/Storage: 10 - With 4 GB of RAM and 64 GB of internal storage, I've got plenty of room to load apps and handle the next version of Android OS.
WiFi/Bluetooth: 9 - WiFi seems fast enough and Bluetooth connected without issues to even my cheapest no-name devices, and remains stable.
Mobile Data and Phone: 9 - Get a solid 4-5 bars with T-Mobile in my area - at least as good as my iPhone, and remains stable. WiFi connection works well and is reliable. Maybe not the fasted around, but good enough.

Overall rating - 5 Stars
Summary: Best phone I have ever had at this price *by far*.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I'm using this on AT&T in the USA, and it works great. It has possibly the best radio reception of any phone I've ever owned. I live in an area with spotty reception. With my old Samsung S4 and S5, it was about 50% odds whether the phone would ring, even if it was showing several bars. My next phone was a Moto X Pure, which would consistently ring as long as I was showing bars.

This Huawei does just as well as my Moto, maybe even a little better. So I'd say that it has a GREAT radio/antenna design.

This phone is awesome. It's blazing fast, has a great screen, great case, solid build quality. Huawei already has an Oreo update for this phone.

I was a little worried about whether I'd like the EMUI interface; I definitely prefer stock Android. And I was a little disappointed that they went with a non-stock dialer. I got so spoiled with the built-in spam alerts in the stock dialer. But aside from that, it's really not too bad. You can tell some stuff has been skinned, but it's not nearly as bloaty as I remember TouchWiz being on the Samsung.

Also most of the apps like facebook don't appear to be cooked into the ROM, because I was able to uninstall them (not just disable).

A few minor UX annoyances:
- They don't appear to have embraced the heads-up ring notification in their dialer...it's full screen even if the screen is on.
- They have an AWESOME built-in way to hide the control bar at the bottom, but no easy way to go full immersive and hide the status bar. (still halfway immersive is better than nothing)
- do not disturb - the status bar icon doesn't show any indication of *which* mode you're in (priority, alarm, total silence). Just shows the same crescent moon symbol for all. (The alarm icon will dim in total silence, if the alarm icon is visible...so that's what I use)
- 8.0 navigation dock - I get that the gestures are kinda cool, but this lost functionality from the 6.0 dock, which had a lock button. I wish they gave you the option to use the old style dock
- "lock screen" widget - works great if you use the stock home screen, but doesn't work if you replace the home screen (I like Nova better)

attaboys:
- this is the first phone that has showed my bluetooth headset battery level...that's awesome!
- came with a very nice TPU clear case...never seen that before!
- insanely good battery life...yesterday after 18 hours I was still at 70%

Warning: If you like root, I was a little surprised after I ordered this to see that Huawei was in the process of phasing out their bootloader unlock code service. I had checked this out when I was researching a few weeks back, but they just made this decision public on 25 May. What the heck! I was able to get my code, but website says in 60 days they will cease providing codes at all.

However even though I got my code, I actually haven't used it yet. I used to use root/xposed very heavily to tweak setup, but honestly with all they've done to allow for non-root tweaking in the last 3 versions of android, I've found there's really not much I actually need root for. I do miss my ad blocker a little bit, but it's a very minor thing, and I don't really have much ad-ware any more.

Also I discovered that you can do a lot of tweaking with SystemUI Tuner. (Huawei disabled the built-in android tuner, which you normally get to by long pressing the gear icon until it spins...but there are non-root apps that can provide very similar functionality. This is how I got full-immersive capability to hide the status bar)

All in all, definitely one of the best phones I've ever owned. And as for the CIA warnings...I don't know if the Chinese government is spying on my text messages...and I really don't care.
Label: Postif

Ulasan: Okay first of all let me get this out of the way. Do not worry about the chinese government spying on you lol Huawei is there to make money by selling phones, period. If you ask me I believe Samsung and apple had something to do with that spying rumor because they want to keep the competition down in America and Chinese phones pose a threat. After all why buy a phone for 1000 dollars when you can get one almost just as good for less than 300. So with that being said, this phone is amazing. Super fast fingerprint scanner, camera quality is amazing, if you handed this phone to someone who didn't know huawei, they would think you paid three times the amount that you actually did. I asked Huawei about a update to Android 8.0 and they said it is confirmed and should be released in April or May at the latest. The software is well optimized and I can get about 6 hours of screen on time with casual use such as calling, texting, and social media. You can zoom in the screen on apps to take advantage of the 5.9 inch screen. The speakers are not the loudest but the quality is good and clear. The audio through the headphones is really good and it also has a mode to improve it even further giving it a bit more bass. The only downside to me is it isn't USB type c, but with how great this phone is all the pros definitely make up for it having micro USB. With phones like this, from Huawei and xaomi, the days of paying 600 to 1200 for a good for are over.

Ulasan:
I'm not the techno phone geek many are but I demand a lot out of my mobile experience and this phone is more than up for it. It's fast, the battery seems to last forever -- haven't gone through a full charge in a day yet -- and my overall experience using it as a phone and a computer has been very good. The camera doesn't do well in low light, but the flash is adequate. Daylight pictures are exceptional. One feature I was meh about before purchasing was the finger print scanner and dang if it isn't the handiest thing ever. I've not had it fail and it gets me inside my phone fast. Flawless.

I'm older and have some vision issues, so I appreciate the large screen.

The phone was not loaded with bloatware and what few little apps I didn't want I was able to get rid of without a problem. I also have had no issue with any of my favorite apps working on this device.

I take all kinds of kidding at the brand and the jokes about being spied on by the Chinese are fun. But honestly I find all's fair in the marketplace and in my estimation this phone is a real winner. I've used Samsung Note 4 and Note 5's, an iphone, and plenty of Blackberry's in my time and this phone tops them all. Seriously a great piece of equipment and an exceptional buy.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I've been on iPhone since before 3g. It's been my only smartphone OS I've ever known. With iPhone prices climbing every year I started to reevaluate my position. I saw Android users have so many phone options whereas my only options were, "do I want a bigger screen?" or "do I want to buy an older phone?" I did a lot of research and asked around and finally decided that I should switch.
The next part was the phone:
So many options. I was concerned that if I got a sub-standard phone, it would otherwise taint my evaluation of the Android OS. I was also concerned though that I would spend $600+ on a phone and I wouldn't windup liking Android. After more research I decided on this phone, the Huawei Mate SE (I still have to look at the phone for the spelling). My thoughts were that for this price point, I could evaluate the OS and if I didn't like it, I'm not out much after a phone resell and if I did like it, I'm not out much to buy a more mainstream Droid phone.
Thoughts on my purchase:
I love this phone. I am coming from an iPhone 6 and everything is phenomenally better. I'm sure I could have gotten a new iPhone __ and also had an improved experience but again, that costs a lot more $$ than I just spent here. I love the OS. There is a bit of a learning curve but after a couple of weeks, things make sense. The Android operating system offers so much more flexibility in it's settings and features. Things are in intuitive places so I am not digging through menu options to find things or having to use a search feature to find anything (coughcoughWindows10cough). I've have been keeping a Pros and Cons list and so far, most of my Cons are trivial things that even if I did use on iPhone, I don't mind them not being there for the sake of all the other Pros.
In Summary:
If you are not HEAVILY tied to all things Mac and are looking for a phone to test the waters of Android OS, this is your phone.
If you are tired of shelling out $500-800 for a phone that you feel the need to throw more money at for insurance/protection plans, this is your phone.
If you think that the "notch" in the front screen looks terrible and is a trend you hope fails, this is your phone.
If you want to buy a new phone that you don't have to finance like you're buying a car, this is definitely your phone.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
First impressions are really great. It's fast. Ample memory. Great battery. Nice camera. Got this phone for the kid, an upgrade from a much-beloved but no longer supported Amazon FirePhone (itself maligned for all the wrong reasons, a story for another day).

The camera has many features popular with the younger crowd (think: filters, background swap, beautify mode, AR ears etc). Android 7, while older, really doesn't bother me, since the latest security updates are available for this phone. We actually like the EMUI interface. May get another one for myself because it blows my older Note 4 out of the water.

If anything negative arises, I will update this review. For now... highly recommended.

PS Worried about spyware claims from US intelligence services and random senators? How interesting that most of these came about once Huawei surpassed Apple in terms of units sold worldwide. Politicized protectionist nonsense, if you ask me. I am really glad that Amazon didn't cave to the misinformation campaigns, unlike BestBuy, AT&T et al. I've had this phone since March, previously owning a Honor 6x. I am very happy with it.

My usage isn't super heavy. I use Instagram, Youtube, Gmail and Google Chrome the most and all these function flawlessly. I take a lot of video / pictures and the camera quality is great. Low light is garbage, but for my needs it does exactly what I need and the price was right

PROS:
The cost is crazy cheap for what you get
Very snappy and responsive, unlike my Honor 6x which slowed down rapidly after first owning it
Nice build. Got a Spigen black rubber case for it and it is the first phone with a case that doesn't feel bulky.
Fingerprint scanner is wicked quick and the placement is great.

CONS:
Low light performance sucks on the camera, BUT in general it takes great photos and has tons of settings you can access.
Some slight software... not bugs... but quirks, if that makes sense. IE: You can swipe from the left across the screen to access extra camera settings, but only when taking a portrait. Landscape you cannot access the settings (as far as I know). Other built in apps have similar oddities, but it really does not bother me.

Overall I highly recommend this phone. For the price I think most people will be pleasantly surprised at the quality they get when they first use this phone. 5 stars.

Ulasan:
I've been using this phone for 3 weeks, and am well pleased with it, especially as compared to my last phone, a Moto X Pure.

First, this one has a fingerprint reader, which is so fast and easy to use that I have finally elected to use a lock screen, whereas, in the past, I have been too lazy to want to deal with it.

Second, this phone has a much better battery than the Moto X had, even when that phone was new. The Moto battery became intolerable after 2 years; I hope to do better with this phone.

Third, this phone rarely gets very hot, whereas using the Moto was like having a heat pack strapped to my thigh.

On the downside, I cannot get Bluetooth on the Mate SE to connect with my 2015 Ford Transit, with the lower-level SYNC package. I am not certain this is the phone's fault, since the SYNC system has been sort of flaky. And, I am able to connect the Mate SE Bluetooth to my OBDII dongle. Fortunately the auto Bluetooth is not a deal-breaker for me, since I rarely used it, anyway.

Another deficit with the mate comes with the external speaker volume: it is only adequate if I'm in a small room with no background noise. The Moto X Pure had a great pair of external speakers.

The Mate's general image quality seems on par with the Moto, and the Mate has a lot more features that may be useful. The Wide Aperture mode is the one that gives artificial bokeh, and allows you to change where focus falls in a photo, even AFTER it's been shot. Test shots in this mode have been encouraging. The Pro Photo mode allows one to specify shutter speed and ISO, though the aperture is fixed at 2.2.

The Mate came with Android system 7, which I used for only a short time before allowing it to update to Android 8. Huawei's user interface is not pure Android, so some things do not appear in the menus that may be expected from reading about Android 8. For example, some of the new options for home screen settings do not seem to be available.

Coming from Android 6 I am not entirely pleased with this version of Android 8. It can be confusing to find settings that I want in the menu. The search function in the Settings menu is helpful, but some features just cannot be found with the terms I expect. I find the mobile data usage graph to be very much dumbed-down.

Some other reviewers have reported having problems with the phone's GPS. You must go into the Battery/Launch setting and make sure that each GPS app is set to allow running in the background. I'm no longer sure whether the default, per-app Auto setting, here, was the problem, or, if I had set some early restrictions myself. AND, the interface, here, can be pretty confusing as to what the default is, vs what you have set. But, it's all good, now.

I've also seen complaints about not being able to change the rather short screen dim and sleep time. Like me, people are going in right away and turning on the Battery power saving mode. But, in that mode, customizing the screen sleep time is unavailable. I finally abandoned use of that power saving mode. It doesn't help all that much. Really, the behind-the-scenes, full time battery savings over older versions of Android are commendable.

While I do not really consider myself a power user of smartphones, I did have to root my Moto X, in order to have unhindered use of hotspot tethering with my service provider. I did not want to go through rooting another phone, because it interferes so much with system update processes. Fortunately, the Mate does do hotspot tethering very well, for me. It did not appear to work at first, but one little change fixed it: I added ",dun" (no quotes) to the APN Type of the Internet APN, under the Mobile Network settings.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I upgraded from the Motorola Nexus 6 (2014). I wanted a phone with good specs that would be a significant upgrade, however I was not willing to pay the price of a laptop for a cellphone. I believe these Huawei phones represent an excellent value due to the current state of trade relations between the US and China. Because of political uncertainty, Huawei has had to alter their original plans of distributing their phones via popular US retailers like Best Buy. They are basically selling direct to consumer now. I'm guessing that Huawei probably has too much inventory on hand since the Best Buy deal fell through. Without marketing or any significant US brand-recognition, these phones are selling CHEAP. You might think there's something wrong with them... there's not. This is a great device! I'm considering buying a second one just to have as a backup. Huawei and Foxconn (Taiwan based manufacturer that handles a lot of the manufacturing for Apple) work closely together. I believe they even share some of the same factory space.

The phone takes two SIM cards at once, it's globally unlocked, and it doesn't come with too much Huawei customization to the stock Android experience. I disabled all the Huawei apps from receiving updates and changed the default preferences back to the Google apps. The only thing I wish this phone had is wireless charging, and that I can live without for a $200 iPhone clone. Oh, it uses regular USB instead of a lightning connector, and even has a standard headphone jack... image that!

Take my advice and give it a try, if you don't like it return it.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
This is a pretty good phone. Does almost everything I need a smartphone for. I use my phone moderately for texting (WhatsApp/Telegram/Slack), checking emails, news, listening to music, uber and few other standard apps and there has been no lag or hanging issues with this phone. It has been pretty reliable.

Pros:
When I bought this phone, I had one important need - Good audio quality. I listen to a lot of music and the iPhone 7 I had before sounded terrible. There is no bass and music sounds pretty flat on the iPhone. I didn't want to spend $500-$700 on an LG phone just for the audio because their update cycle is bad. This phone has pretty good music output. I wouldn't call it the best, but it definitely sounds better than the iPhone 7 (I use Bose QC25 headphones).

I don't click too many pictures on my phone and whenever I need it, it does the job. If I really need to click pictures in the dark with bokeh and all that jazz, I would use an actual camera for that purpose and not rely on a phone. Don't care about selfies, so even if there was no front camera, I wouldn't notice.

The battery is terrific for my usage. With my regular usage with maps, music, YouTube etc, I end the day with almost 40% remaining. I have pushed the phone for 2 days straight on a single charge. I get about 5.5 - 6.5 hours of screen time on an average.

The fingerprint sensor is fast! I barely brush it and the phone is unlocked. I don't have to look at the screen to do it.

Also, this phone doesn't have the ugly notch on top and that's a huge +. I can't wait for the world to move on from the notch abomination and until then, this phone is a winner for the price.

Cons:
The screen is a bit too big for my liking. One handed usage is a bit of a pain. But I installed Nova Launcher and found some workarounds (swiping down on the screen for notifications etc).
The auto-brightness isn't accurate. It's usually calibrated to lower than what I would've liked. I'm constantly increasing the brightness.
The screen itself isn't the most beautiful screen, but that's not a major concern.
Doesn't have USB-C but again, never bothered me. I just swapped the lightning cable to the micro-usb cable next to my bed and I forgot about it. As long as the phone charges and holds the charge well, I don't care if it uses usb a b or c.

Bottom line: If you are budget conscious, need a phone that does the job, this would be a great buy.

Ulasan:
There are dozens upon dozens of reviews singing the praises of this phone, and I don't disagree with most of them nor will I repeat those accolades. But there are issues.

Bluetooth, generally:
I connected this phone via bluetooth on three devices: two car radios (factory Toyota, Pioneer AVH-270BT, Bose Soundsport headphones). It runs into two issues with all three devices:
1. The range is terrible. Get any further than a few feet from the paired device (e.g., putting the phone on the seat of the car, or leaving the phone on a desk and walking a few feet away) and the signal drops out.
2. It stops working after two days. It will connect, but you can't hear anything nor can anyone hear you (if you're attempting to make a phone call). Rebooting the phone fixes that issue.
(These issues also plagued my Huawei Honor 5x).

Bluetooth, in video messaging apps:
It doesn't work for Facebook messenger or Whatsapp. You can hear the dialing tone through the headset, but that's it. They can't hear you, you can't hear them. I have to disable/disconnect the bluetooth device to use video chat. Uninstalling / reinstalling the apps, factory resetting the phone - none of those things resolves that issue.

Bluetooth and Wifi:
You've read about this ad nauseum. I have issues with streaming music and web browsing - it (at least for me) prioritized the bluetooth stream over loading the webpage (which, I guess if I had to make a choice, I'd make that one).

Camera:
Terrible. It is perfectly serviceable if you have no intent to look at photos on anything other than on the phone itself. Printing photos or viewing them on higher resolution devices isn't advisable. You can make a pinhole camera that takes better photos.

Speaker:
Think of it as an earpiece on the bottom of the phone. Don't expect it to be a serviceable speakerphone anywhere except in a quiet room.

Screen:
Perfectly fine if the image or text is static. It has ghosting issues when you scroll or watch fast moving videos (e.g., football / basketball / hockey highlights). Brightness and colors are fine, though.

Included jelly case:
This case makes the phone more slippery than a wet bar of soap. I think Huawei intended for you to drop the phone repeatedly and upgrade to the Mate View 10. Sneaky, Huawei, very sneaky.

Okay, those are the negatives. Positives:

Android OS, EMUI: Oreo runs beautifully. It was actually a joy to use the device on a daily basis (outside of the above issues).

Headphone jack: 1. It exists. 2. It sounds fine for earbuds.

GPS: Surprisingly excellent. I've had no issues in the city or suburbs. Google Maps with the PIP works very well.

Fingerprint reader: surpasses everyone, including LG and Samsung.

Space: 64GB with a MicroSD slot? Good lord.

Battery: It can go nearly two days easily.

Device: classic iPhone style, copied by Huawei perfectly. Improves upon the iPhone design with the inclusion of a headphone jack. It looks like a premium device, and feels solid in your hand.

Call quality: Great. I used it on AT&T's network. No issues getting LTE coverage everywhere I normally received LTE coverage. Calls sounded good over BT (when it worked) and over the headset.
Label: Postif

Ulasan: I have this phone for about a month now and I can easily recommend you to get one. In fact, I liked so much that I bought the gold version for my younger brother. So far I haven't experienced any major lags or slowdowns. There will be some minor lags, but not so much that you'll really notice or get bothered by it. There are three things that you should consider when buying this phone which is the speaker, the ear speaker and there aren't that many good screen protectors and cases. The speaker is not that loud, but for $250 I can't complain. When making a call you might want to be in a quiet place. I found myself having trouble hearing the person, but the audio is clear. I've bought a few screen protectors and most of them don't fit or causes the rainbow edge effect. My advice is to not purchase any temper glass screen protectors for this phone.There are many cases but the quality isn't that great. Right now, I'm using this case https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0794ZYN4D/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 and although it doesn't have the best grip I like it a lot. It is a bit bulky but I like my phone to be a bit bulky so consider this when purchasing this case. Besides these three issues, this phone is fantastic and a major go. The screen is huge, the camera is decent but I don't use it that often, the phone is fast with no feelings of slowness, and the fingerprint sensor is usually accurate and really fast. So far $250 I think this is an absolute buy and a great deal. It is also said that it will be updated to Android 8.0 but don't quote me on this.

Ulasan:
Arrived on 12/31/2018 to replace my old phone which had broken.
Things I like:
1) Very simple setup once you enter Google credentials. It even copies over your application data
2) Beautiful phone, thin and sleek-looking. Huawei logo below the screen is understated and does not detract from the appearance
3) Comes with cheap, clear plastic case
4) Fast performance
5) Screen brightness and resolution are fine
6) The price (presently $219.99) seemed to give this unit the best value compared to other options considering all of the features (4GB RAM, 64GB storage), recent version of Android

Things I don't like:
1) With its 5.93" screen, this is a large phone. It fits a pocket easily due to being thin, but the feel in the hand is not ideal. Unfortunately no one is making a quality phone with these specifications and a 5.2" screen. Popsocket actually helps.
2) The Huawei company has been a subject of national security concern over the last year or so. Huawei has a Phone Clone application that you are encouraged to download to ease the setup of the device by copying data from your old phone. This works great, *but* you have to wonder if Huawei is keeping a copy of your data, hacking your password info, etc. based on the government issuing official statements that we should not buy Huawei phones. If I end up being hacked in the near future and they drain my bank account, I will be sure to update this review.

Ulasan:

I do all of my banking, all of my reading-books, newspapers-everything on my phone
I text, message, and talk on my phone and use it for GPS maps.
I love, love, love this phone. It's light, sleek, good size, nice display, great speedy charging, and is very reliable. Never had it stuck, paused, or shut down during use.

Doesn't get better than this.
And that nonsense about Chinese using these phones to steal from US

So try one of these out.

Ulasan:
I have this phone for about a week. I could not have been more pleased. I had bought a Moto G6 and was not pleased with it. I figured I would try this one.
My criteria were 1) Less than $250, 2)3GB RAM and 3) 64GB or disk space, and of course an overnight charge that can last a day. This phone more than met those. Actually had 4GB of RAM (better than the G6), was less than $250 and I charge it once every 2 or 3 days. The picture quality is amazing. The speed is blazing fast.
I am not the kind of paying 1K for a fancy phone, yet I do consider this phone as quite fancy. I doubt these fancy phones have bells and whistles that can justify the price differences. The only thing I can't really speak about is the camera. I don't use my phone for pictures. If this is something big for you, then I would research this a bit more. For me a phone is a phone, not a camera. Still it does make excellent pics and nice movies. I use my phone a lot, and it does wonderfully well in every aspect.
The only thing that bothered me when I was looking for a phone is that it come with Android 7. As soon as I turned it on, it updated to android 8. So nothing to be bothered about anymore.
Highly, highly recommend.

Ulasan: I bought a Huawei Mate SE cell phone from Amazon.com last May, unfortunately only a few months later it failed to work suddenly without any noticeable signs. We sent the cell phone to a cell phone repair shop for diagnosis and repair and were told that they could not repair it because the motherboard had problems so we had to contact the manufacturer. After contacting Huawei Technical Support USA, we sent the device to Huawei repair center. Surprisingly they sent it back to me and mentioned that my cell phone had water damage, and that I cannot get it repaired since water damage void warranty. In fact, this was false as the cell phone was absolutely not in contact with any water, how can it been damaged by water? Furthermore, Huaweis support team sent a falsified image of my phone with the incorrect IMEI number as proof of liquid damage which was not of my phone. I feel cheated by the company not just from its defective phone but also its deceptive support.

Ulasan:
OK - yes this is a 'cheap Chinese phone', but it is fast, has a good feel, and plenty of battery life for the way I use it.
It also cam with a minimal amount of blot ware, which is a huge plus! Yes, it probably has spyware installed, many phones do, but I am not stupid enough to have private information on my phone. Duh!
The 4 GB of RAM, and the built-in 64 GB of storage is more than I'm likely to need, but if I do need more then the 128 GB micro SD card I installed has that covered.
With my previous phone (BLU), if I tried to listen to music on my BT headset with the phone in my pocket, it would drop in and out frequently. With this phone I have a solid connection all the time, including up to 20 feet away from the phone. Sweet!
The camera takes sharp, clear pictures. No it does not have image stabilization - darn it (grin) but I am satisfied with what it does. Give them 2 years and I bet they will have that covered as well.
The screen is sharp and clear and I can comfortably watch movies or read for hours without fatigue. A real plus!

UPDATE: (4 star) - So far so good with replacement unit. I set it up and gifted to good old Mom and she loves it over her old tier 1 Samsung cheapo trial phone. It's fast, long life and a great camera compared to what she was used to, and MUCH easier to see the big screen for her.

Ulasan:
Adobe Flash Player is required to watch this video.
Install Flash Player
...Yeah I know I said that about the Kata M4
But I think the Huawei Mate SE stole that title.
FYI this phone is known by other names.
Honor 7X and Nova 2 Lite.
Pros.
The battery life.
I can see why tech reviewers on YouTube have waxed poetic about it. Don't believe me? Please see my screen shot.

Build quality.
It's solid and clean. Nice metal back with a smooth glass screen. The camera lenses is glass too.

The OS.
I normally like stock Android better but Hauwei's EMUI has won me over.
It's super easy to customize without rooting/jailbreaking.
It's fast and intuitive.

It has Micro SD card support.
This makes me happy because I keep most of my music, pics and videos on a micro SD card.

It has OTG support.
OTG means On The Go. I can connect a USB thumb drive, keyboard or a mouse.
See my screen shot.

WiFi
It can be used as Mobile hotspot or a router bridge/extender. Best of all, it's done natively, no need to download an app.
VPN is also natively supported.
Doing stuff like web browsing, shopping or email is fast.

Processing Power and RAM.
It's got 8 core processors and four gigs of RAM. It handles multi tasking like a champ.
So far I haven't noticed much lag.

Temperature management.
Pretty solid in my book.
I keep my phone in a case.
So far I haven't noticed the phone getting hot while charging, using and being in the case at the same time. The charger doesn't even get warn.

It has a regular radio. No need for a subscription or internet connection.

GPS. No complaints. I tested it by looking up my job's location.

OK Google ( AI assistant.)
It works well enough for me. I tested it by asking "Who played the Goblin King in Jim Henson's Labyrinth?"
Not only did it understand me, it gave the correct answer! David Bowie
(If you have a speech issue or a thick accent then you may be better off typing your inquiry.)

The finger print scanner.
This is another thing that YouTube tech reviewers have waxed poetic about.
It's very erganimicaly placed at the back.
It doesn't get in the way of the camera.
More importantly it's fast and accurate.

It has a gyroscope.
It can accurately track your steps. Even if you put the phone in a purse Very handy if you're trying to get fit.
Works well with Pokemon GO too.

Time.
The clock is accurate. Heck I've used the timer function for baking. It rang when it was supposed to and my blueberry muffins didn't burn.

Multi tasking.
Remember Picture in Picture by Magnavox?
Lol this phone can do that too.
App Twin .You can be logged into two Facebook or two Twitter accounts at the same time! You know businesses in the front, party in the back! You'll need to turn this on in the settings.

Display.
Nice and sharp! I keep my brightness level around 40% and have the auto brightness adjusting turned on. I also have the eye comfort option turned on. My eyes say thank you Huawei!
Videos, art photos and text look good to me.

Accessories.
This phone came with a case. Do iPhones come with a case?
If you don't like the one that came with it then there are other options. If you can't find one for the Mate SE, just get the Honor 7X/Nova 2 Lite cases. Like I said before, same phone just different names.

And since it has a headphone jack, any headphone, earbuds or wired speaker will work with this phone.

Headphone jack!
A thin $230 phone has a headphone jack, imagine that!

The microphone.
I tested it by making an audio note and calling a friend for a ride. My buddy said he heard me just fine.

Accessibility.
Fingerprint to scroll.
Smile or use victory/peace sign to take pics.
Flip over to mute calls, notifications, alrms
ect.
Love it!

Predictive text.
OMG. I'm terrible at typing. If it wasn't for this option, you wouldn't be able to read this review.

Built in emojis!
Lots of cute ones to choose from like cherry blossoms, cats, and fruits.
If you like texting with emojis then this is the phone for you!

Now for the meh. Meaning not good but not bad.

This phone does come with a bit of bloatware. But I actually do use some of them.
It has one speaker on the bottom right corner.
Sound quality can get a little tiny on high volume. If you are holding your phone in landscape mode then you might accidentally cover the speaker. But look on the bright side, at least it's not at the back

Camera. The rear one has an LED flash but the front doesn't. If you want to take a good selfie you'll have to use the rear camera or find a location with good lighting.
There is no image stabilization on either camera. But you can compensate for that by using a tripod or selfie stick with a gimbal. Or just lean on something. Or just edit any blurrness and shaking in post production.
I took a few sample shots.

Charging.
It's not super fast but not too slow either.
The way the OS manages battery consumption makes up for this in my opinion. It takes about 2 hours to go from 0 to 100.
No wireless charging due to the metal back.
The charger port is not type C. This may bother some but not me. I'm fine with that because I can still use my OTG dongles.

Bluetooth connection can be a little spotty at times but it maybe the fact that my other phone is broken. I'll update this part later.

The phone supports dual SIM cards.
SIM card slot one supports 2G,3G and 4G speeds but slot two only works on 2G.
And you can not be using both at the same time.
If you were planning on using this phone for business and personal calls, you might want to look elsewhere. Anyway I bet most folks would rather use the second slot for the Micro SD card.

Cons.
NO NFC or Hot Knot support. Just a little FYI. That means no Google Pay or transferring files by touching screens together.

Pre installed apps can not be deleted or moved to the SD card unless you root/jailbreak.

Battery is not removable, unless you have the tools and skills.

Final thoughts
Please give this phone and Huawei a chance.
This phone looks and feels luxurious. One lady on YouTube even thought this was a $1,500 phone? LMAO.

Don't believe everything that the government is spewing. They say the Chinese government is using this phone to spy on us.
Not sure how dust and water resistant this thing is. OR drop damage ressistant. I'm too chicken to test that. If I ever do drop it down some stairs or in the sink, I'll let you know.
Label: Postif

Ulasan: I have purchased a few of these...they are excellent phones that run Oreo with Huawei skin. The build quality, display, and battery life are very, very good. I don't care about NFC, so this phone does everything I need it to do. It is very responsive and the battery does not get hot (like my old iPhone). I have dropped mine twice...once very hard...and it was fine. The Huawei skin is a little Apple like, but not in a bad way. Paying $230 makes a lot more sense then $700-$1200 for an iPhone. I use Cricket and it seems to play very well with ATT/Cricket.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I'm a tech-savvy Galaxy Note 4 owner, and I've wrestled with buying an upgrade for months, ever since AT&T pushed Android 6.0.1 on me last year, my beloved Note4 has been unstable, cranky, and crashy. I had looked at the Note 8, and I didn't like the price tag approaching $1000. I also didn't like the Samsung treatment of Android 7. So I kept looking. The downside of other non Galaxy-note phones was they didn't have all features, but I could come close. This Huawei Mate SE is the closest I found to the Samsung S8, S8+, and Note8.in terms of specs and features.

And still, I was hesitant, because the Note4 had become a trusted friend over the years, even though it was suffering from unreliability.

After getting the Huawei Mate SE, all that worry went out the window. The Mate SE is SPECTACULAR.

Setup was a breeze, migration of my data, apps, etc from my Note4 using the Phone Clone software in the SE was flawless (of course it is smart and didn't move apps that weren't compatible) and moving everything took less than 45 minutes. The heart and soul of my Note4 is now in my Huawei Mate SE. And wow, does it ever work great!

PROS:
Fast - browsing, scrolling, app launching, everything is super fast compared to my Note4. Octacore processor
Good screen- easily readable, fast response auto-brightness control, crisp and colorful AMOLED
Fingerprint reader - placed properly, instant unlock, integration with some apps in lieu of password,seems to never fail
Dual SIM cards - one for work phone# one for personal#
Storage - 64 GB and 4GB RAM same as Galaxy S8/S9
Great camera - almost as high end as S8/S9 with HDR, time lapse, slo-mo and audio control
Superior reception - added two bars in most every location using same provider
WiFi Hotspot - works great where previously wouldn't on same provider.
HUGE battery - 3340mAh - S8 has only 3000 mAh - S8+ 3500mAh
Overall experience is like a Galaxy S8/S9 - minus the Bixby annoyance
Figured out a way to make it take notes like Note4/Note8
Supports "Bring Your own Phone" SIMs for all major carriers. I'm using AT&T
Comes with a clear protector case
Price - a $800-1000 class phone for $250 - DEAL!

CONS:
No Gorilla Glass screen - tough glass but get a screen protector for $10
No water resistance like the S8/S9
Bluetooth seems to be limited to one connection at a time - not a big deal, worked with my Dodge UConnect just fine
Screen res 2160x1080 where S8/S9 has 2960x1440, but this made text easier to read for me, so maybe a plus.
Rear camera doesn't do as well in low-light conditions as Samsung
LED status indicator on top right is a little small for my tastes
No wireless or fast charging - but charging still faster than my Note4

There was some news recently about the U.S. Government flagging this phone (and other Chinese mfgs of phones) as having spyware embedded. AT&T was going to offer this phone in their line, and pulled out at the last minute because of this. This was a political move, not a technical one, because the Feds wanted to protect Korean mfr Samsung at this time of historic North-South Korea reconciliation. I ran Norton, Kapersky, Malwarebytes, and a others on my stock boot-up of the Huawei Mate SE and found nothing. This claim is just political BS and even the U.S report doesn't say the actually found any, only that it is "possible"

In summary: after months of searching, I'm pretty happy with this phone, and I'm glad I bought it. Can't beat it for the price. If you want a good modern phone without all the extra price and bling features, this is it. Copy/paste in browser to buy and give me a small tip: https://www.amazon.com/Huawei-Mate-Factory-Unlocked-5-93/dp/B0791VS3N9/ref=sr_1_3?s=wireless&ie=UTF8&tag=wattsupwithth-20

Ulasan:
I've used the phone now about a month and can adequately give my 2cents. The phone is amazing (and for under $220). The camera is fantastic. The battery is a workhorse in longevity. The speaker is adequate. All the standard android apps are pre-installed. Navigation is very easy if you are familiar with Android interface. I have owned the Huawei Honor 8 phone for about 2 years prior to this one, but was looking for something with more internal storage (64GB), bigger display. The phone hits all the buttons.

The only criticism is the "Micro-USB" charging port, cable. I would rather had this phone been built with a "Type-C" port. The phone charges much slower than my Honor 8 did (which has Type-C). But the battery seems to last longer with the same amount of use. There is no reason to spend $900 on an iPhone X or a Galaxy S9 when this phone is a solid workhorse. If this phone were broken, lost, stolen or damaged I wouldn't be crying over the $220 spent on this phone. Good choice for a budget conscious buyer or looking to get a phone for your phone phone-abusive teenager(s).

Ulasan: I really enjoy using this phone, and I laugh every day that I didnt have to sign a new contract with my cell phone provider. I had a 6plus that wouldnt hold a charge and kept freezing so it was time for a new phone. Ive had this phone for 3 weeks and I can tell you that I will never pay $1000 for a phone again, nor will I spend the extra $35/ month to lease a phone and then 18 months later not even own it and have to sign a contact once again. These cell phone companies are making record profits not only on the cellular service but on the mark up on smart phones. Buy this phone and be free of indentured servitude. With moderate use, going on Twitter, watching Netflix, and texting throughout the day, this phone holds its charge for 1.5 days. In my opinion this phone does just about everything the $1000 phones do except the sound quality is a little less than par. But really, is that worth being locked into a contract and worth also paying $750 extra? Happy shopping!

Had the Mate SE for about a week. First impressions it installed well from scratch though the Android 8 update took overnight. It's fast and screen navigation is excellent. Features like my own ring tones installed flawlessly. One gripe a lot of the native themes and images are not easy to turn off or Uninstaller. It does let the user opt out of the native Huawei apps like subbing Google photos for Gallery. But then when on tries to customize wallpaper and Screensavers from Photos the Huawei Android blocks access. So far that is the only negative. Doesn't feel like a $200 smartphone. The included poly case is very adequate. Screen is big real estate. I like it a lot. Tons of free Ram and lots of extra memory even without an SD. I feel hooked!

Update after 1 month: super fast, very responsive screen, tons of storage. Tends to slip out of my trouser pocket in the car, of course because its so big. Screen super bright, I am running it at 40%; no pixels apparent. The bottom row of buttons that were hardware on old phone are soft and change between apps in this version of Android. Will probably add a thin glass screen cover. The 5 stars are secure...

Ulasan:
This is my third Huawei phone. The one thing I really appreciate about them over other smartphones is they are simple unlocked smartphones that are not loaded with bloat. Likewise moving my information from my old honor to this new phone was extremely quick.
The display is crisp, the camera works well, and apps perform as they should.
Now there is one new thing I noticed on the phone, and that is the camera app has a great deal more these days.
Now mind you...feature bloat has become a thing and higher priced phones usually take more battery life and are more fragile.
Either way, I am not likely to move off of Huawei if they keep offering decent unlocked phones at an affordable price. It is hard to find a phone this good with these specs at this price level.

Ulasan:
I bought this phone based on a coworker's recommendation. I'd owned by ZTE Pro Max for a few years and was desperately in need of an upgrade. I received the phone, switched it over to Metro PCS with no issues, and it's quite quick and responsive. Apps act as they should, and overall it feels good in my hands.

So why the two star review? Having only owned it less than two weeks, I've already encountered a couple of major problems.

PROs

Very responsive in terms of speed
Updated to Android Oreo (8.0) with no issues
Easy to configure

CONs

Sound Quality - I'm hard of hearing and it's significantly quieter than other phones I've used, even on max sound settings.
Screen Quality - I'm a klutz, so I put every phone of mine into hard cases with screen protectors. I owned my ZTE for 3ish years and I've dropped it more than once with minor scratches to show for it. I dropped this once from my nightstand (about 2-2 1/2 feet high) and I have significant cracks along the front of the phone. In the end, it's my fault that it dropped, but the fact that it could be cracked by such a small distance (even through its case) serves as fair warning to anyone that might be considering this phone and deals with the same issue.

I'm going to keep the phone and eventually replace the screen with something better. I just wish I didn't have to right out of the box.

Ulasan: I have had this pretty awesome phone since April 2018 & over all I am pretty darn happy with it. It has a pretty decent battery and with a proper charger with an output of 5V, it charges pretty fast. Plenty of memory and with an added sd card, I have way more than enough for now even though I'm constantly recording videos. Picture quality is decent and has a lot of edit options. I've been using a few unlocked phones since my Galaxy S5 & and this phone feels top of the line. The fingerprint sensor is awesome. I do wish it had a louder speaker and my GPS sensor seems to be on the slow side. I am not sure if that GPS issue is due to the dozens of drops it received already. I cracked the screen once and had it replaced with an Huawei Honor screen and that one ended up cracking as well, but it is way more resilient and has not deteriorated to where it needs replacing.

Ulasan: So far I am very happy with this phone. I am never wasting a ton of money on a phone again! It is reasonably fast and has been very reliable. The display is very good. The battery is very good and so far easily lasts 2 days with general use. I do not play games on my phone but I do text often and perform the basic things like checking my e-mail, banking, phone calls, Facebook, etc. The phone handles these tasks easily. I have only been using it for a week or so but so far I could not be happier. The camera is adequate. I read some reviews knocking the speakers but I don't listen to a lot of music or anything like that on my phone. I have played a few videos off YouTube and I thought the speakers were fine. Phone calls sound good to me. If it starts acting up I will update my review but so far 5 stars all the way.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
Well, I have had it about a month, but so far, it is amazing. After reading many reviews here on amazon, I was convinced it was a good phone. I am glad I purchased it. My previous phone was the Zenfone 2 Laser, I definitely feel like this is an upgrade. I am not a gamer, so I havent tried any games, but as far as videos, browsing, and other apps, everything is top notch. Very responsive UI, no lag. Phone came with Android 7, but I checked for updates right away and it updated to Android 8 and the latest version of EMUI.

This is my first Huawei phone, but I have a feeling it won't be my last. At this price point, this phone performs as well as the more expensive ones.

Was concerned a little about volume since there is only 1 speaker, but it does just fine. Call quality seems great, havent had any complaints.
Screen is bright and colors are vivid...I am impressed. Nice job Huawei. Love It.
Label: Postif

Ulasan: Having owned several iPhones since their launch, I got to the point where every next generation was more disappointing. I decided to save $800 and try the Huawei, a brand I was familiar with in Europe where they've had a presence for many years. Is it as good as an iPhone? Probably not. Is it an excellent phone? Absolutely. I've had it now about 3 weeks, have gotten used to android, and couldn't be happier. If I only keep it a year I'm good. If it drops and breaks it's cheap to replace. It does everything I need it to do. The speakers are not great, but adequate. The photos are not excellent, but good. Screen is great. Finger print work well. Functions are as they should be. I paid $225 odd for this, and that's a bargain. Good battery life, quick charging, and I just bought a memory card to boost this thing... You won't go wrong, unless fashions, brands, and bragging rights are your weakness.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
2nd Edit: After receiving replacement phone - 4 STAR REVIEW

Amazon quickly sent my replacement, and I'm in love! The speaker phone still sounds fuzzy, people tell me. But me, I'm thrilled. (The workaround is to use WhatsApp, speaker becomes awesome!) Additionally, the notifications ping & flash accurately on this phone, so I can tell what's a text & what's the phone. Anyhow - overall, best phone I've ever used. I'll update again if it falls apart but so far, I'm LOVIN' IT. I had to dock it 1 star for the sketchy speaker phone but heck. It's still good.

Edit: One week later - 3 STAR REVIEW

Soooo sad - I've started having the phone jack & speaker phone issues others mentioned. Headphones didn't work while plugging in on a work-related call. And I cut out & people couldn't hear me when using the speaker phone. I'm gonna return & try to replace with a new one & will update again. I SO love this phone.

At purchase: 5 STAR REVIEW

Just purchased...but looks like, this is why the US is trying to keep Huawei out of the country - they'd put Apple out of business. And def Samsung, with its slow-loading speeds on devices (at least the older ones).

I'll update my review later, in case the phone dies or whatever or I find new things to like. I haven't played with a lot of the functionality, mostly used in normal operations, but here's what I can tell now:

Pros:

- It's the fastest device I've ever touched. Loads faster than I can blink almost, unbelievable. This alone is a reason to purchase, I'd say. I measured it side-by-side with a Nokia 6, to gauge loading times & in most cases, this phone was speedier. Sometimes notably so.
- Fingerprint scanner/phone unlock in the back works 100% of the time and it's amazing not to have to use a password anymore.
- Ability to easily split screen & have two apps open is really cool.
- Camera is amazing, both selfie & regular views. Fast shutter speed. Allows macro photography. Captures photo ok in different lighting (though I haven't taken a lot of photos against windows yet).

Cons:

- No normal text notifications. The LED is very small & hard to see, so that doesn't really work. I read up on how to set tonal notifications, but now my phone rings like a call when I have an e-mail. Somehow I got texts notifications to ping, by playing with the settings. I'll still have to research how to get this set up right. It's def weird.
- The speakerphone isn't as good as the Nokia 6, for example, when I play music. Lacks bass. I'll keep playing with equalizer apps & see if this improves.
- Speakerphone during regular calls (to Canada) is more muffled than when I use Whatsapp! Not sure why this is.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I am glad I bought this phone. It is a great value for $219.00 plus tax. I do not experience any connectivity issues with bluetooth or any other device. It's fast and reliable. Fingerprint reader is extremely fast. The volume can be turned up quite loud. The camera is pretty darn good too. I really have no complaints and I'm pretty picky about this type of stuff. I'm done with expensive smart phones and hope this lasts a while.
If you're looking for a great value I recommend this HUAWEI.
Label: Postif

Ulasan: I've had the phone for about 6 months now, after my friend recommended it to me as an upgrade to my S6. The phone material feels high quality and it has a decent weight to it. Since it's a bit longer than average phones, it does kind of sit awkward in the hand, and sometimes it can be rather difficult to reach all of the screen while using it with one hand (I'll just blame me having small hands.) My phone had some weird bubbling under the screen, but it hasn't impacted usability, and if I chose to, I could send the phone back to have it repaired as it is a manufactures defect (I haven't though, due to pure laziness and the fact that it's pretty easy to tune out.) Apps run snappy, but some may have display issues due to the longer screen. I personally haven't come into any who have had the issue, but I get the prompt every time I expand an app to full screen that there may be some issues. The back camera is good, I can say that it is better than the S6 but can't say the same for the front camera. I can't tell if its the OS and the UI that limits the function of the front camera (like being able to focus on a face while taking a selfie) or if the front camera is just bad. Either way, I can't really be upset. The true winner of this phone is the battery life. You can go all day with moderate to heavy use and by the time you go to plug it in at night, there will still be half a battery left. It's a good phone for a tight budget, but let its low price convince you that it's low quality.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I had been waiting to get a new smartphone for a few years. The smartphone I used prior to the Huawei mate se was the iPhone 5, which I started using in 2013. It was fine for a few years until the iOS updates started slowly down my phone and shortening the battery life. A few years ago the iPhone 5 was no longer supported, and I was left with a phone that was not too useful anymore. Somethings I liked about the iPhone 5 was the camera, the iMessage, and the form of the phone. What I disliked was the amount of memory, amount of storage space, general slowness of the phone, the apple apps filled with ads, the touch detection accuracy, and the low battery life. Since I have switched to the Huawei mate se, my iPhone is being used as a iPod touch which has to be recharged every 2 days to be used, even if it is turned off.

What I disliked about my iPhone 5, I looked for in the recent smartphones. The Huawei mate se was the cheapest smartphone I could find that was the best fit for what I was looking for. It has 4 GB RAM, 64 GB storage space which can be expanded with micro SD card, a faster processor, a bigger screen, and a long battery life. Compared to my iPhone 5 which required recharges every 2 days, I only have to recharge my mate se once every 5 or so days. The camera is somewhat comparable to the iPhone, but does not seem as clear regardless of the mode. However it looks like it has more customizations when using the camera. Since this is an Android phone, it is lot more customizable that the iPhone. It runs on EMUI which is Huawei's Android variation, and it updated usually every month with security patches. The fingerprint sensor on the back of the phone is very handy for unlocking the phone. This phone has been an improvement to my life since I have switched smartphones. The only issue I have been having with my phone is with messaging. There are occasional instances where my group messages are sent and lost, but there is no indication that these messages disappeared into thin air. The only way I have been able to solve this is to get to area where the mobile data reception is 4 bars or greater before sending the text.

The phone comes in a white box inside a cardboard box. It comes with a plastic phone case that can be used unless you want to switch to a decent phone case. There are no screen protectors, and the SIM card slot pin is provided. Getting the phone setup was easy, and it was easy for me to switch from using iOS to EMUI.

This is one of the best cheap smartphones out there right now. If you don't want to spend $800+ to get a fancy iPhone or Samsung Galaxy, this phone may be for you.
Label: Postif

Picture quality is better than most of the low budget phones. It does not have NFC which is a must for me since I use Google pay often. Wifi connection has intermittent issues that gets extremely slow for no reason. I thought it was the router but the other devices side by side has no issues. Huawei is a budget phone and it gives you exactly what you pay for. BEWARE.
