Ulasan:
Good phone for the money with one MAJOR flaw for me. This phone can't stream to Bluetooth and do WiFi at the same time. WiFi speeds become unusable. Tried to figure out why. Looks like they share the same antennae on the phone. Bummed out as I use Bluetooth headsets daily. (I have had other budget phones that handle the Bluetooth and WiFi issue just fine.) Other than this it's a good phone for the money. Surprised because the build quality other than this is good.

2nd radio/issue found - GPS. GPS is less accurate than other phones. I compared to 4 other phones I own and this one is the furthest out of calibration/inaccurate. I expected it to not be as good as my Samsung Note 5 but it also got beat by a phone half it's price. If GPS is something you depend on (especially in the vertical/alt side) then this may not be the phone for you. I tried with 2 different Mate SE's and both have the same problem. Maybe they can add some correction in software but I am assuming it is an antennae / metal body issue.

So much about this phone is great but it really struggles on radios which is essential to a phone. Disappointed because otherwise would be great!
Label: Negatif

Ulasan:
Bought this for my wife after her Samsung finally gave up the ghost. I am one of those cranky old farts that feels cellphone prices are close to obscene. That being said I did some pretty extensive research on affordable phablets/phones and kept coming up with Huawei. While it lacks some of the uber cutting edge whiz-bangery of the latest iFarce or Samsung Pocket Lighter, it does have an excellent camera and a processor that is fast enough to work any app one would use.
Aesthetically pleasing, easy to work and about five hundred bucks less than one of the previously mentioned overpriced over-hyped wallet rapers, this phone strikes a sweet spot for those of us that need performance without paying Ferrari prices for a dang phone.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
Even cell phone pros were impressed. I had my reservations, I have had quite a few smartphones over the years, and have only owned the Nexus 6p from Huawei. They had improved significantly from the 6p. Buttons have good feel, phone is snappy, software is decent. Camera quality is pretty good, but slightly overexposed in my short time with it.

Bought for my mother in law, and there was no sense in getting a $1,000 phone that will mostly be used for calling. For what it is, I could genuinely see using this phone as a daily driver if I were short on cash. Obviously I prefer my Pixel 2 XL, but I can tell you this is one darn decent phone. Battery is above my expectations as well. Screen is bright, and big. Easier on older eyes with the Android software letter increase size.

If you're looking for something "good enough", this phone is a hit. Politically, I don't care what Uncle Sam says about the espionage potential of Huawei. If you are worried about that, avoid smartphones in general. Could snag up a big roll o tin foil too....
Label: Postif

Ulasan: I've had this phone several weeks and I love it. My battery lasts in to the second day. I surf the internet quickly and effortlessly, the camera is better then adequate, the response time is lightning quick, gaming (though I don't do much) has no lag time, and as a phone and texter absolutely no complaints. Is it as good as a flagship phone? No. There is a reason they cost three and four times as much. The thing is I don't need whatever those reasons are. And that's what you should be asking yourself. Is it ego, or do I really need that flagship phone? Because if you don't then buy this one. It's a great performer, with a fabulous display and a build that should last a very long time.

Ulasan:
Ok so I'm terribly rough on phones. A decent ones last me a year hopefully. This one has been great so far. Only complaint is Android auto doesn't seem to work. Tried two different cables and keep getting a no connection error. The thing that sold me to buy another::;
I crushed this phone with a pressure tank to the shape a mild c. I was pretty upset after having it only two weeks. Picked it up and the screen was not cracked. In fact I bent it back to almost normal shape and it is amazingly working as normal still. No glitches screen cracks or anything. This is almost as bullet proof a phone as any I've seen. Super glad I'm not replacing it already. Specs seem good and all loads and downloads seem fast and equivalent to an upper end smart phone. Bottom line is I will need to buy one for when I inevitably kill this one but for now, a 400 lb pressure tank didn't kill it so I'm pretty happy.

Ulasan:
I work in IT so my tech level is really high. This is an AMAZING phone! I mean granted I don't own the IphoneX or Note9 but I do have to say, the fingerprint reader is sooo fast. The facial recognition is sooo fast. Screen is sharp and VERY responsive. There were 2 or 3 updates I ran which brought the phone to EMUI 8 and Androind 8. It's just amazing. For so much speed and quality at such a cheap price I can't imagine any better. I know diminishing returns would occur for higher end phones. Don't get me wrong. I am sure flagships are better, faster, whatever. For me though, this is beyond expectations! people looked as asked of is that the new samsung? And I grin ear to ear! Nope, it was just over 200! and their faces are priceless! I am not at all worried about China tracking my movements. Nor should anyone else! That is a political mind game. The FBI, CIA, NSA, and Homeland security have been able to do that since 2000! If, by chance you are one who can not be tracked and MUST stay under the radar. I would suggest do not buy technology. The screen is bright, bright enough for me. There are many little nuances that make me really appreciate the phone. It's quick enough to charge. But, wow I really really like it.

I shopped around the only other thing I might have changed is the new "pocophone" might be better but was ~70 more and too new to get my hands on. In the future I might look at that line.
Label: Postif

Ulasan: Huawei has made such incredible strides by leaps and bounds and at a blistering pace that they were technically run out of the US. Ridiculous shame. Here you have a phone, as with all their phones, that has excellent battery life, a really nice screen, acceptable sound, and everything on it works pretty much flawlessly. And all of this for just under 250 bucks. I still have my Galaxy Note 8, and about 5 minutes off the charger at around the same screen brightness of the Mate, the battery begins to deplete. At 100 percent battery, it can be well over 30 minutes before the Mate begins to deplete. They can put a 5000+ mah battery in the high end phones (like Samsung), and the incredible quality of their screens is still going to race right through that battery. Why does anyone need a supposed high end, super bright phone? And frankly, how many people use the seemingly 75,000 tricks and this and that on these so-called flagship phones?? Most of the stuff on them that supposedly consumers want, but honestly you will rarely if at all use, is simply useless. At 250 bucks I am hard pressed to see any kind of real difference that a 1000 plus dollar phone. It takes calls flawlessly (my note 8 has issues with calls, especially on Bluetooth), it works well searching on the net, screen is plenty bright at just over 50%, sound is more than acceptable (I am not looking to use it as my stereo), and I don't game so I could care less for that. Build on it is solid. The added case is more than acceptable. I don't understand how it is people are constantly dropping their phones! It comes with all you need out of the box, minus headphones. Great unit for 250 bucks - period.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I have had all types of phones. I have owned both Android and iPhone. I decided to buy a device and have money left over. This is the perfect device. This phone is fast, has a great screen and the battery life is the best that I've had.
I've owned the device for almost a month and I am completely satisfied. The size of the screen is awesome and the phone can be easily held in the hand. I love that it also comes with a case. Just pop your sim card in and go! I'd like to think that Im into media consumption and this is the best device. If you want a great device and don't want to spend $1000, this is the device for you!
Label: Postif

Ulasan: If you need a new smartphone and have a GSM carrier (AT&T or T-Mobile), this is a great phone for the money. 4GB of RAM means plenty of room for all your applications (unlike my 2GB Moto G4 that kept force-closing apps if I opened more than one at a time) and activation was a snap: just remove the SIM card from your old phone and put in this one. Porting everything over was a breeze thanks to Huawei's app that copies over all your apps, pictures, etc. I find the OS to be snappy and responsive. The built-in launcher (EMUI) isn't the greatest, but a quick installation of Nova Prime solved that. All in all, this phone is highly recommended!
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
So far so good. This is by far the highest quality mid grade phone I've ever seen at this price point. 4gb ram and 64gb with a surprisingly decent camera. I'm using it with metro PCS and it's flawless so far.

Operating system:
Upgraded to Android 8.0 Oreo.. it's buttery.
Smooth transitions from app to app and very little lag, if any at all.

Display: absolutely stunning at this price point. I'm used to the Galaxy AMOLED screens and the screen on this phone is the closest I've seen to AMOLED at this price point.

Battery life:
So far it's pretty standard. Don't love it, don't hate it.

OVERALL: I certainly feel that I've gotten my moneys worth. The phone isn't plastic either, it feels and looks like a $800+ flagship phone. This phone is sort of like an Android and an iPhone had a baby. Blown away and very happy with my purchase. Even came with a clear phone case.

I will update this review in a few months and let you know if the phone is worth 8t in the long run.

1 month after purchase:

Phone is still working perfectly without any major issues. I have to say, I'm blown away by the battery life on this phone. I'm the guy with his nose in his phone 24/7 and I rarely go below 50% battery life.

Only thing I can say that I've experienced that isn't so fun is the response time of the touch screen. Scrolling isn't as fluid as my old Samsung and sometimes I have to tap something more than once to get it to go.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
For the Price this is not a bad budget mid range phone. VOLTE works on Mint Mobile (mvno of T-Mobile). This phone does not support WIFI calling. It does have T-Mobile bands 2,4,12 - but is missing 66 and 71 for other main bands used. With that said I have not had a connection issue in my location. Out of the Box this phone updated to Oreo 8.0.0.341(C567). With Huawei budget phones though I am not sure how long they will support updates though. Unfortunately Huewei does not allow unlocked bootloaders as of this spring so keeping the phone up to date in the long run with Community Builds is not an option. Overall the phone does have 64 gb storage for a 2018 budget phone and does work well when paired with T-Mobile and it's MVNO's with the correct APN settings.

Other Notes: The Phone only has 2.4 Ghz Wifi, which does work well - would be nice to have 5Ghz. The Bluetooth paired with both of my cars - however it is choppy compared to my Oneplus 3T. Also the GPS is not a real strong suit for this phone. I was able to succusfully use GPS Status & Toolbok to help calibrate the GPS to within error of 4.9m which is pretty good. Ulasan:
I buy alot of smartphones. Typically, just flagship devices. This is my first budget/mid-range buy in years. I purchased because my old S6 Edge Plus would last about 2 hours SOT before dying. Where I work I need a reliable battery so after some research and not wanting to spend much money, this and the essential phone were the options.

What I can say is this.. The phone performs as good or better than my $1200 galaxy S6, except in sound and camera. The camera will definitely bum you out if you're used to having the higher end Google, Sansung or Apple devices. But, in good lighting it's not half bad for HDR shots. In low light or in video though you'll start seeing where it falls short. The sound.. pretty bad. Kind of loud but "tin can" sounding and actually hurts at full volume (high pitch, zero low end sound)

For the good.. This thing is quick, quicker than expected. After a week of use Ive had zero crashes or lagg at all. It works very fluid. And the battery is the best part! Ive had the screen on for over an hour and I am at 91%.. I'm not used to that. Sure, the Essential phone would have had a better processor and camera (maybe) but with 4 gigs of ram, and a killer SOC and Battery, I'm very glad I went this route.

It is slippery, and though they do provide a case (pretty cool Huawei!) it's just about as slippery. I'd really recommend getting the Poetic or Spigin case on Amazon when you order.

I definitely recomend this phone! And service on t-mobile in norther california is great. My old Galaxy wouldnt get phone calls in my house, this one does. So it even has better radio/antennas then a phone that costs 4x as much. Huawei wanted to get a cheap device in america almost at cost, to get people more into them, and it's working. This thing is a powerhouse and could have easily cost 400+ is it had "Samsung" stamped on it somewhere and people would buy it.

One last note.. if you're into the iPhone's look but not the software, this phone is the one for you. Almost identical to a 7+, with excellent build quality just like Apple.

Hoe this helps! If anyone needs help just send a message and I'm happy to answer any questions.

Ulasan:
After losing my 4th iPhone to water damage (my own fault), I just couldn't justify purchasing another $700-$1000 phone. Apple makes great products,but their premium tech comes at a premium price. This forced me to look towards android. I saw this phone on amazon with exceptional ratings and I decided to take the leap.

After a week of use, All I can say is Wow! What an amazing phone, especially considering the price tag. It feels like a device that's two to three times more expensive and comes loaded with a crazy amount of tech. As a longtime apple fan, I've gotta say that this is pretty amazing. The screen is beautiful, the processor is faster than my iPhone 6, the 64 gigs is more than substantial (I installed a 64g micro SD (another benefit over apple) so memory is effectively 128g), and the fingerprint sensor is faster and more effective than any sensor I've used before. It's thin, lightweight, feels good in the hand and the nav buttons are intuitive and easy to use. Perhaps my favorite feature is the battery. Even as I write this review I've been using the device pretty heavily today (at least 7 hours of moderate to heavy use) and I'm still sitting at 82% battery. That's phenomenal.

The front camera is great, mostly when using the pro mode, although it's easy to wash out pics especially in high sun without adjusting the settings. The selfie camera does leave a bit to be desired (image quality seems lower than the 8mp they advertise, sometimes appearing grainy) but that's not a huge deal for me. My final caveat is the speaker. It's fine for browsing videoes and that sort of thing but don't expect it to get loud. I almost struggled to hear calls while on speaker phone with minimal-moderate background noise. It's not a huge deal since I just switched it over to the ear piece and the call quality was clear and loud.

Bottom line, this is the best phone I've ever owned considering the amount of tech vs the price tag. It easily feels like a $500-$600 device. I'm a fan.

PS the Chinese government has yet to contact me and my credit card accounts remain secure. I think we can stand on the huawei tech threat.

Ulasan:
This review will focus on one of the major complaints that I read here in Amazon reviews both before and after I purchased my Huwai Mate SE. No need to rehash all the stuff that is good about this phone, plenty of other reviews for that but I was having problems with some Apps. But I found the solution so now everything works.

90%-95% of Apps work right out of the box
Over 90% of my Apps worked from the get go, when I set up the phone and imported all the settings from the old phone I was good to go for most of them but there were primarily 2 that did not work right.
1. Mileage tracking App (in my case it was Hurdlr)
2. Call screening/blocking App (My fave didn't work and I downloaded 4 other ones and none of them worked)

The reason these Apps failed is because of Huawei's built in "feature" called Protected Apps. You will find it in Settings in the Battery section. You have to make a change in how your phone manages the battery with respect to certain Apps.
In Settings>>Battery there is tab called Launch. Under the heading "Manage all automatically" you must turn off the slider for App, which will place the App in the group "Manage batch manually". When you go there you will find check boxes now next to your App that you can turn on or off:
Auto Launch
Secondary Launch
Run in background
For my Apps that weren't working before I have all 3 boxes checked and they are working fine now!

I already liked my phone from the appearance, the size how it's large enough yet fits easily in any pocket, how it receives calls all over the house in places where my previous phones could not. But fixing this last issue, certain Apps not doing what they should, takes it over the top and it's clearly a 5 star now especially considering the price.

Update: some common defects people have reported
1. Bluetooth and/or WiFi: I have not had any issue with this at all. My calls are crystal clear in my car. No WiFi problems on 2.4 Ghz.
2. GPS: No issues, I use Waze and Google Maps, both have worked as well or better than on any other phone I have used in the past. My previous phones often had a tendency to get very hot while navigating, the Huawei Mate does not!
3. Camera Quality: Ok,my Sony Xperia had a better camera but it also cost nearly double the price. I don't expect to get a top notch camera at this price point. However, it is more than adequate for my needs. If I need more I will take a camera with me.
4. Battery Life: some have complained about this but my phone lasts for 2 days easily with normal use. If I play with it a lot or do a lot of navigating without it being on charge then it might only go 1.5 days.
5. Reception: the radio on this phone works better than on any other phone I have ever owned. I receive calls in areas of my house where I often wouldn't and I'm experiencing very few call drops even while driving.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I had a BLU Advanced 5.0 prior to getting the Huawei Mate SE, and it was a decent starting smartphone. I decided to upgrade to something with more processing power and internal storage. I spent a long time looking at other bargain phones with exceptional quality and features, and I finally chose the Huawei Mate SE.

It's been a great phone. It runs quickly even with a weak signal on my MetroPCS plan. The display is surprisingly good for something that is not a premier phone; even the video and sound compare really well to the iPhone 7 (the choice most of my family prefers).

The camera, although it takes objectively good-looking pictures, produces somewhat grainy macro images, even at short distance, which was something I found slightly disappointing.

However, its battery life is incomparable. I can play music and get GPS directions on the road and still have about forty-percent of battery life by the end of the day.

The 64 GB internal storage is great as well, since it guarantees plenty of storage for pictures and video. The phone runs fairly smoothly when I run three or four apps at once - especially Google Maps, Amazon Music, and the camera (I use the phone as a dash monitor).

If I ever had to get another phone, I'd definitely recommend a Huawei product.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I really wanted to like this phone - its characteristics are great and it looks and feels like a higher-end product. However, I could not make a compromise with the quality of the sound. Whether using the phone speaker, or whether placing a regular call, or whether using a car bluetooth device with it, the sound is hollow and sub-par, worse than the sound of any other phone I've owned in the past 5-6 years. I also found the phone screen to be less bright than expected even at higher brightness levels. I've never used Huawei products before and while their EMUI is pretty similar to the standard Android interface, I found it a bit of a downgrade in terms of navigation. The phone also comes with Android 7.0, rather than with 8.0.

On the positive side - the phone makes good pictures in bright daylight and its fingerprint sensor works seamlessly. Its battery life appears good but not phenomenal. I used the phone almost non-stop for about 4 hours (installing software, browsing the net, etc.), during which time its battery level went from about 60% to about 15%.

Overall, the price tag is very attractive, but only if you are willing to make a compromise with the quality of the sound. I am returning the phone because I listen to a lot of music through my cell phone, and need something that sounds good. This Huawei model does not.

Ulasan:
This was purchased as a replacement for my broken OnePlus 5T which was a beast of a phone. My 4 star rating is relative to its price, don't compare this to a Samsung S9 or iPhoneX.

Summary: Get this phone to save money, get a large display, and the current design style. Its reasonably good for gaming, watching movies and everything else you want from a smart phone. BUT, as I said, its no iPhoneX or S9.

Pros:
Price  Mate SE $250 vs. $1000 for the cool phones. I've had expensive phones, they're not worth the extra $750 IMO.
Looks  It looks as good as most highend phones.
Battery Life  At 100% charge I start my day at 5:30AM: Gaming 1hr, Youtube for 1hr, GPS track my jog 1hr, google maps, web browse for an entire day and still have maybe 15% by bed time at 11pm.
Weight  Its light for its size
Screen Resolution  FHD+ | 2160 x 1080 ... It's not QHD, but anyone who says they can tell the difference on a 6" screen must have superhuman eyes.

Cons:
WiFi  Connects to 2G not 5G for me. Thats ok, still plenty fast.
NFC  No NFC. That's ok for me.
USB  Uses old school Micro USB vs. USB-C. This is good and bad.
Charge Time  1% between 1.5 minutes to 2 minutes. SLOW.
UI  Example: Accessing the camera options is confusing.
Crashes often when I have Youtube playing in the background but not when I'm actively watching.

Its a phone made in China, so it may be spying on me and sending my data back to the Chinese Government. But that's ok, I'm not looking at anything worth their time and most likely you aren't either.

Ulasan:
After several years of purchasing top tier phones, I got tired of spending that kind of money on a PHONE. Spending around 1K to make phone calls, check email, IG, surf, and watch the occasional Youtube video is ludicrous.

Coming from a Galaxy Note 6, I wasn't prepared to be impressed at this price point, but I am.

Pros:

Price point - I mean, seriously.
Size - great to hold. Slim and the 18:9 screen makes the shape comfortable.
Quick - the processor is quite quick and 4GB of RAM is nice.
Less uninstallable software than carrier branded phones
Unlocked
Fingerprint reader - wow is this thing FAST. Love it.

Cons:

Screen - definitely not AMOLED which is what I'm used to. This is the biggest drawback, but I understand that it would have upped the price a bit. However, I would have paid the difference. Some things look a little washed out with little depth to photos, etc.
LED notification - wow is this thing TINY and not bright at all. I wind up checking my phone more often when in silent or vibration mode. My Note had a nice bright LED which I customized the color per application.
Charging port - no USB C. Maybe next time.

This is from about 1 week's worth of use, so I plan on updating on reliability in a few months.

Ulasan:
I bought this phone for my sister a few months ago and she loved it. Just had another family member looking for a new phone. I saw this same phone on sale and recommended it to them.

The phone itself is definitely not a flagship phone but for a mid range priced phone, it's not bad at all. My sister plays games on this phone and didn't have any complaints. The family member I'm buying this for is definitely not a gamer and only uses it for lighter tasks.

He previously owned an LG G6 and this phone was a bit heftier in weight and the screen size was also larger on the Huawei Mate SE. The response times are pretty good most of the times. I noticed slight lags once in a while but nothing too bad. Setup was simple and we were asked if we wanted to bring our data and apps over from the previous phone. It's done using the Google account so apps can be automatically downloaded back to the new phone. The phone downloaded about 20+ apps and were were on our way using it shortly afterward. The apps were responsive and we didn't notice any lags.

The phone came with a cable, charger and case. The case is the slim TPU type which won't offer much protection if you drop it. All the buttons and ports were accessible so that won't be a problem for those who are more careful and prefer to use a slimmer see-through case.

We took some pictures and the quality were not bad at all. Definitely not photographers here but we mainly use the phone for taking pictures on the go or on vacations. The phone pictures quality are pretty good these days so we usually don't need to have a separate higher quality camera on hand.

The audio from the phone is pretty clear when we played back videos and made phones calls. No issues so far.

Overall, glad with purchasing this phone again at a good price. It's perfect for anyone who doesn't need to use any app/game that consumes a lot of CPU and memory. There's no problem playing most of the games and I know my sister plays a handful of games on her phone.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I got this phone to replace my aging Blu Life One X. I'm mostly happy with it, but there are some issues with default settings that could stand to be a little more user friendly.

The most egregious example is with the default music player, and how Huawei really, really expects you to use it, whether you want to or not. Apps also (by default) don't keep running after the screen locks, which is kind of a pain in the ass if you just want music while you're driving, or cooking dinner, or if you hate yourself and decide to go jogging. You have to really play around with power, permission, launch, and cache settings to use play store apps in place of the OEM stuff. I should note that my phone updated to Android 8 the day I got it, so I never got the chance to see if it was the same on Nougat.

Hardware-wise, it's easily the best phone I've ever owned. The screen is lovely, there's a generous supply of ram, and I didn't even really need the extra micro SD storage space. I don't have anything to compare the fingerprint reader to, but it seems fast enough. A solid buy for $230.

Ulasan:
I really like this phone but it is starting to come apart in the lower left corner.

After talking with Huawei support I learned that a simple 1 foot drop onto carpet will void the warranty if you have any damage that can be assessed as physical damge. Now I have a phone that was in a case to protect it and slipped off the couch, that has a screen separating from the case and they will not repair or replace it. I am not happy with this at all. I have had other phones endure much more drops and they were still covered. I can't believe a company would want to make this right.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I love this phone. I purchased my first HUAWEI when my Samsung Galaxy Note crapped out after only a couple of years. I wasn't willing to pay the exorbitant price for another Samsung flagship. So I bought a Huawei Honor 6x. So when my husband's phone died, he took over using the Honor 6x and I bought this one.

The memory is great. The fact that it has ability to have a memory card inserted is great. The photo quality are crisp and clear. I was able to connect it to my carrier (StraightTalk) by just inserting the SIM card is definitely a big plus. I love everything about the phone except for the screen.

I read a lot on my phone and I also use it to write notes to myself when I'm away from my computer. The touch screen is not anywhere nearly as responsive as the Honor 6x. And if you add a screen protector, it is horrible. Touching anything near the edges of the screen involves repeated touching, sometimes pounding keys on the virtual keyboard (when I get frustrated). I have given up on using screen protectors for that reason. I now live with the fear I will drop the phone and the screen will crack. And I am so frustrated at times, that I consider finding a different phone.

This is the only reason I've given it the number of stars I have. And had the screen been as peppy as the Honor 6x is, I'd have given it five stars
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
Likes:
Photos of front facing camera are very good to excellent quality.
Very good battery life, i.e., usually more than 1 day, i.e., 1 to 2 days, even with heavy use.
Quick start up
Little to no bloat-ware if you buy an unlocked phone and insert SIM card from a vendor
Instant fingerprint recognition to make security an ease
Good size, i.e., decent screen and still fits easily in pocket
Affordable

Dislikes:

SERIOUS LIMITATION: The major problem I have with this otherwise very decent smart phone, is that the contact information only allows searches on names, titles, and organization fields. A search on contact information using a Samsung phone would generate a search on ALL contact fields. So for example, if you wish to search your contacts for people or companies you know in Chicago or Denver, you can't do it with the Huawei Mate SE. If you used the "Note" field in contacts to indicate friends or businesses who participate in various activities like SCUBA, Skiing, etc., or perhaps you use the Note field to indicate contacts who provide resources for your mother or other family member, searching Huawei Mate SE contacts for "SCUBA" or "Skiing" or "Mom", will NOT bring up any information. Furthermore, if you search Huawei Mate SE for the string "MD", it will bring up contacts with MD listed as their title, but it will also bring up irrelevant names and organizations which contain the letters M...D, such as Mary Dorney and Mark David. So whereas Samsung "Makes it possible" to search contacts for relevant and useful information other than name and organization, unfortunately Huawei "Makes it IMPOSSIBLE" to search contacts for such information.

Other dislikes include:
Rear facing (selfie) camera takes poor quality photos.
Camera HDR mode seems to have little to no impact on photos.

If it wasn't for the serious limitation on searching contacts, I probably would have rated the Mate SE a 5.
Label: Postif

Ulasan: Firstly, I came from and LG G5 and used an battery case that gave me an additional 150% charge. So, with basically 250% battery my phone would barely last 20 hours total, all I really did was play music from my music player while I worked. Before that I had a Samsung Galaxy 5, that battery was better but still lacking. This phone gets me through an 8-10 hour shift of constant music streaming from Tunein radio with about 60% left on the battery. Just incredible. Now, for some reason my sd card kept coming back as malfunctioning and my music on that would not play. Nothing that the app Poweramp did not fix on that end. The camera itself isn't that great, but serviceable. The speaker isn't overly loud, either. But for me these weren't big concerns for me. The phone is excellent overall, and the price is very low for what it could be. I did buy mine on sale for $219. Very happy with this device.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
Great Phone! Updated to Oreo with no hiccups. Cloned my old phone and transferred all my data and apps without any hiccups. The phone is so customizable and intuitive. I upgraded to this phone from a LG stylo 3 and it blows rings around that phone. My only gripe is the camera, under certain lighting conditions it can be a little washed out, but you can always tweak the settings to clean up the image. I have been recommended this phone to anyone who will listen. If this phone lasts for more than a year without any major problems, Huawei has a customer for life.

And unless you're working for the military or government,I wouldn't be too concerned with the Chinese hacking your phone. If Huawei is able to move forward and put this behind them, I see them as a formidable competitor in this arena.

Ulasan:
It's a great phone for the price. I was looking for replacement for my Moto (battery dying slowly). Moto g6, Nokia 6.1 and this one were the options, I choose Mate just to try something new. I'm not regreting it.
Body quality is great, I like slim design and material quality. Shape it great, despite a big diagonal for my taste it doesn't feel big in hand.
Screen it bright, angles are ok. It's fast. Immidiatelly after getting online it grabed Oreo update.
Battery it good, 2 days without problems with normal usage, location and BT are constantly on. Old USB port is convinient if you have stock of old chargers.
The only downside noticed so far is luck of fast charge. While overall charging time is average, about 2 hours it's linear function of time, which can be a problem if you forget about it in the morning and need to run fast.
Camera is average, while portrait mode is good. Also spent some time removing rubbish preinstalled apps.
Overall its a great phone, I would buy it again.

Battery life is great, phone is snappy, more than enough RAM, and added a 128GB sd card to it for plenty storage. It has one minor issue however, and that is the bluetooh. It can be a little dodgy, especially when switching between calls and streaming music. The bluetooth also slows down the WiFi speed, because it shares an antenna.

That being said, the bluetooth issue is not enough to lose a star, because the phone itself is solid.

Ulasan:
Hello. I purchased this phone May 1 2018 to replace an old note 4.

Major issues:
1. This phone has some bad GPS tech. I use my phone for hiking and car navigation since google maps is more accurate than my garmin navigation at times. In my city, my phone will constantly drop gps signal (searching for GPS signal). I am forced to add my garmin navigation as well because my phone will lose signal like 20 times. I took this phone too the woods many times and had countless issues locating my position.

2. The touch screen is bad as others have claimed. Sometimes you must double touch in order for something on the side of the screen to be activated. My old note 4 ironically had a much better screen and it did not suffer from this, even though it was an insanely old phone.

Conclusion: I have no issues with anything else, however the GPS thing makes this device a total waste of money. I regret not waiting for a drop of other competitive android products that are pricier. You live and learn. Save your money and go for their android competition.
Label: Negatif

Ulasan: Recently, my wife decided to drown her Samsung Galaxy 5 and this phone was purchased, by me, as a replacement. Ulasan:
I've been using this phone for around 6 months and it's easily the best phone I've had.

Build Quality-
The build of the phone is solid and has some weight to it. Granted I have a case on it, I've dropped it a couple times and not a mark on it. The touch sensor located in the upper middle on the backside is a good location and easy to reach, works very well.

Screen-
While not a 4k screen, it's full HD and looks incredibly sharp. The colors look very sharp, and you're able to change the color temp in the settings which is a nice touch.

Speakers-
While only one on the bottom right side, they're fairly loud and sound pretty good. Nothing spectacular, but they get the job done.

Cameras-
This is where the sacrifices were surely made. In low light, the camera quality is pretty bad. In normal lighting they're OK, so if you're keen on photography you'd be better off looking elsewhere.

Battery -
This is a huge thing for me since I'm a heavy user. I'm always streaming music, watching videos or surfing the web. The battery easily lasts me the day, 12-15 hours, with 40% left to boot. In the off chance you need it, there's the standard battery saver, and the very handy ultra power saving mode at 10% that puts up a black screen with only the bare necessity apps for communication.

Performance-
This phone is no slouch, it's incredibly fast for the regular tasks. It can multitask very well without any hiccups. As for gaming, I'm not too keen on mobile gaming but I imagine this can handle most apps you throw at it. For a visual spectacle this might not be an ideal phone for you, but that's up to testing.

I'm very happy with my purchase!
Label: Postif

Ulasan: This phone is a vast improvement over the more expensive LG phone I had before. I don't use the camera very much, but I have taken a couple of really good pictures with it, one portrait and one landscape. Physically the phone is very solid, and survived a couple of drops with the included case, and a purchased screen protector. It has a large bright screen, and does not come loaded with crapware, although Google manages to sneak some in. Note that this is a GSM phone, only valid for ATT and T-Mobile in the US, and in all the rest of the world. I managed, with very little help from my service provider, to make the transition from my old phone.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I was looking for a smartphone that if I dropped in the toilet I wouldn't be too upset over, but I wanted large size because I am a large man. So I wasn't going to pay for an iPhone or Samsung, and didn't want to spend more than a few hundred dollars. I have been a customer of TracFone for years, and I knew they have a Bring Your Own Phone program. I saw this phone at Walmart under an AT&T subscription. So I did a little research and figured out that buying a factory unlocked phone and a TracFone AT&T SIM card would suit my needs. I purchased both from Amazon, and went about the set up when they arrived. As soon as I turned the phone on, it began auto updating it's software and apps. This took the better part of 20 hours! They only real issue I had was that altho I used Tracfone's website to activate the SIM, it didn't happen. After 3 days of no service, I went to the TracFone's website and used the Chat feature with an associate. The SIM activated and the number ported in about a half hour. BINGO and Win Win!

Since I began using this phone in late July, twice I have gotten automated calls from AT&T to verify the account. First it asks for the last four of my social security number, which I typed in. Then it asked for my AT&T account number. At this point I did not enter any number. After asking twice more, the computer gave up and said Thank You! I never lost service.
As to the phone it is really very good! Altho like all Android phones I've had it doesn't allow you to completely delete unwanted apps, or move them to the SD card memory, it does have the ability to stop updating the apps you don't want and thus save the phone's memory.
The SD micro card and the SIM both live in a pop-out tray. If you travel internationally, this feature theoretically allows you to obtain a SIM card in the place you are visiting pop it into your phone and you are ready to go.
Other reviews have panned the camera quality in low light on this phone. I can't say I've done enough pics on it to notice, but I was buying a phone, not a camera.
All in all I heavily recommend this phone and the TracFone system to anyone looking to purchase a larger smartphone for 25% of what an iPhone or Samsung costs.
Label: Postif

Best budget phone in my opinion. Got to try this for half a day when it was sent after cancelling my order.(waiting for the Huawei View).
As with other reviewers, this is smooth as butter, fast, and just beautiful. I read issues about the wifi slowing down when using bluetooth , which I confirmed to be true, but not that bad compared to my Note 5 which slows down too when using both. If not for the upcoming release of the other Mate 10 Pro variant, I would have kept this one. If the "View" won't impress me, I might just reorder this one again.

Ulasan: Very affordable phone with big screen and fast processor. I don't play games on my phone, but it's got more than enough juice to handle Netflix and Youtube. The call quality is great. The fingerprint sensor on the back is very fast. The only negative is that I could do more with the fingerprint sensor on my old Honor 5. On my old phone, I could launch different apps using different fingerprints, so that made it very convenient to make calls and play music on the fly. This phone doesn't seem to offer this function, otherwise it would be a 5-star rating.
Label: Postif

Ulasan: This is a pretty good Android phone. The fingertip lock is in a weird place, on the back of the phone, but after a while you get used to that. My big beef with this phone is that, no matter what I try, the sound for an incoming text message is so faint as to be almost indeciperable. And when you're waiting for a text, that is an important feature. My late iPhone had a nice clear bell tone that was easy to hear, but this phone just doesn't seem to have the capacity for a loud text alert. If anyone else has solved this problem, I'd love to hear about it. Otherwise, I'm happy with itl
Label: Postif

Ulasan: Love this phone! I have had it for several months. This is the first non flagship phone that I have owned. The only thing it is missing is NFC, which I don't use anyway. Bloatware is almost non existent. User interface is smooth. Phone is plenty powerful. Camera is acceptable. The phone is a nice size. The screen, while not OLED, is of solid quality. I love that it has a micro SD card slot, although if we are being honest, is not as big of a deal as it once was. My experience with this phone has been so positive that my Sister and Dad have both purchased one too. Solid purchase.

Odd thing I noticed after using this phone for a few days: I'm left handed, therefore I hold the phone with my left hand and support it with my right thumb.
Unfortunately the speaker is exactly in the spot where my thumb goes on the bottom. I keep turning up the volume, wondering why the sound is so low. Then I move my thumb and it's loud.

No other issues I can think of yet after using it for less than a week. Will update later if anything comes up.

Label: Postif

Ulasan:
Like it so far. A bit slower on some games than iPhone 8, some weird patterning issues in background stuff, can't change notification volumes without changing ringtone volumes.
Nice weight, nice size.
Color palette is a rude awakening after Basic Amoled Galaxy for the past 5 years. Hurts my eyes a bit even with eye safe setting and twilight. No auto-stabilizing on video and photo. This is a biggie if you like to take photos. Still a good camera, though, even if low-light (as many people have said) is not good. Battery? Better by far for certain games than a similarly aged iPHone 8. Lighter than iphone 8 even with the Spigen case on. REALLY light with the provided Huawei case on. Overall, a good deal on a great phone. No real complaints.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
After a month I'm very happy with the Mate SE, much more so than the Honor 6X (which I returned). Bright screen, always super fast, uses the 4G LTE bands that AT&T operates on in my area, really good call quality, more than ample storage, decent-or-better camera, and the EMUI is more customizable than the Honor 6X's version. The fingerprint sensor is a welcome time saver.

The phone has only two mild downsides for me: 1. The media speaker placement and volume aren't great, but they aren't horrible either, and I don't need booming speakers from a phone. 2. The notification LED didn't work until I downloaded, installed and configured the Light Flow app. Now the LED works. It's small and dim compared to what I was used to, but it's visible enough.

The Mate SE ships with a case but I opted to buy a tougher one, the Spigen. https://www.amazon.com/Spigen-Rugged-Huawei-Resilient-Absorption/dp/B076V3D2F5/ref=sr_1_2?s=wireless&ie=UTF8&qid=1529708632&sr=1-2&keywords=huawei+mate+se+spigen Glad I did. Dropping phones had been rare for me, but I managed to drop this one twice in only a month, and with no ill effects on it. Would the standard case have protected it? I'll never know and I don't care. I trust the case I bought.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
This Mate SE is my second Huawei and has a few shortcomings. It will not access a 5G wireless router whereas my 5 yr old Mate 2 would do so. The battery life is shorter than my Mate 2, but not a real problem.
Having said that, in other ways, the Mate SE is superior. The display is clearer; the colors more vivid, the camera superior, the bluetooth is far better, the overall speed of all the functions is pretty amazing
Setup was extremely easy, and all of my settings, contacts, apps, etc, imported via Google with just one touch. I don't swallow the spying nonsense and barely gave the spiel a thought. I would recommend this phone with the caveat about the 5G and battery life.
Label: Postif

Ulasan: I placed the order for a new Huawei Mate SE phone Sunday and got it 2 days later as anyone would expect via Amazon Prime. I have been waiting for my holiday gift since the order was completed at Amazon. This is my second Huawei phone. So, my expectation is very high. I have had my Huawei Mate 8 for almost 3 years with great experience: great battery life, much better camera than other big name's, running smoothly, and no damages after dropping many times etc. I still use it with little issues. So, I decided to get a Huawei phone again for next 3 years or longer hopefully. This time, I like to get a smaller screen size, specifically a little less wide than Mate 8's. After finishing my order at Amazon, I can't wait for receiving the new phone - Huawei Mate SE. Wow, it is an amazing phone after playing it a little bit. The size is just a great fit with my hands. Installing a few popular Apps runs very smooth. There are a lot of popular Apps pre-loaded on the Mate SE. I will explore more features on this Huawei Mate SE...

Ulasan:

Too early to say how durable battery will be, but so far so good easily a (light) day use and more. Couldn't be happier.

Ulasan:
This is an awesome phone considering the price point. I already own a blu vivo 8 and this is a much better phone in terms of performance. The mate SE runs very smooth with little to no lag. The phone just performs like a flagship phone. i really don't care that it doesn't have usb type c because all my previous phones were micro usb. except the Blu pure xr which i owned briefly. The only issue i have with the phone is the display which comes out of the box looking a little bit too warm. Luckily , this can be adjusted in the display setting menu. The colors on the display are a little bit muted and i would have loved it if it was more saturated , which would have let the colors pop out more. I wish they would have put a color saturation slider in the settings menu, honestly i don't know why phone makers don't have this option by default (The closest i have seen to it is video enhance on the note 8). This phone seems to have the same color issue with the Pixel XL 2, although google fixed that with an update. I hope Huawei will also update the color saturation and make it more vivid. This is still a fantastic phone, which i have no regrets buying. I have no problem recommending this phone.
Update: I recently noticed that the brightness of the screen would automatically dim when I open apps even though I have got auto brightness set to off. Huawei needs to look into this issue.
Label: Postif

Overall great product at a great price!

Ulasan: I have had the phone for a couple months now. I am coming from an HTC Desire 510 with 8 gigs of storage.. 8 gigs! So anything would have been an upgrade. One problem I had initially with the Mate SE was that I couldn't receive mms messages (group, Pic, sound texts, etc.) I figured out I had to reset some apn settings I found on cricket's website. Some negatives: the sound quality isn't the best, but it's as if I have gotten used to it and it doesn't bother me anymore. The phone has also spontaneously restarted itself a few times, but it's not been a big deal. It feels like good sturdy hardware but it is very smooth and slippery. I'm happy using the clear tpu case it came with. The camera is fine for my standards. I like the 64 gigs of storage and 4 gigs of memory. It's pretty zippy. I LOVE the fingerprint scanner on the back and the ability to pull down notifications with it. The scanner is fast and accurate. I like the display. I'm using a nova launcher and it all functions great. Very happy for the price I paid.

It also comes with a free clear case which is nice, most companies don't do that. So it's great for casual users unless you really want to spend 4-5x as much for a flagship phone.

Only one day in and I am blown away. I had a surprise last week when my Samsung S8 screen stopped working all of a sudden (no drop, nothing). Took it for a screen replacement which was going to cost $229 plus tax. Got a phone call from the tech saying the motherboard was shot. Awesome.

Anyway. After a bunch of research I decided to pull the trigger on this budget phone. I liked the aluminum back and the specs seemed good enough. So happy!!

The UI is better than Samsung's for sure. Photos not quite as good. Speed seems the same in apps. Fingerprint on this is far superior to the S8 (better placement and faster).

I'm really impressed. And heck. If something happens to it I am only out $229. Win win. By this phone.

Ulasan:
Huawei continues to deliver high features at a fraction of Samsung or Apple. I needed another phone as my honor 5x was over 3 years old. I was still impressed with what my old handset could provide but outdated Android Software.

Which networks; Apparently no one can read the Amazon Description GSM: In Mu'rica T-Mobile or AT&T. I use Straight Talk AT&T no issues

Pros:
Metal Silver Case; looks sharp and included a outer protective sleave to protect the finish.
Finger Print recognizer is faster than my Honor 5X
Camera what an improvement. I'm taking less fuzzy pictures
Uploaded Huawei Themes; now it emulates icons similar to Samsung or Apple. Cool feature and free
Screen is beautiful and battery has lasted about as long as my old honor 5X throughout the day.

Struggles:
I had to reinstall the GMAIL app. Got hung up trying to sign in to multiple accounts.
Bluetooth seems to struggle on initial setup with headphones. Still pairing with vehicles will update.
No USB C. Slow charge like my older 5X

Overall I am impressed. I purchase my phones outright because I do not finance a phone for two years. Seriously, is that Phone X worth $999 that is made next door to the Huawei Chinese Factory for a quarter of the price?

Update:
Included Android 8.0 Oreo updated on the the west coast the best coast 11 May 2018 on a budget phone.

Ulasan:
I've had this phone for about six months and I use it heavily every day for work and play... Is been Absolutely flawless!!

The touch screen had EXCELLENT responsive, the screen is large and very clear, the phone is Fast with a 2.36G octa core CPU, 4 gigs of RAM and 64G of storage.
Apps open usually in a second or less, web surfing also loads pages in less than a second most of the time. Phone switches beautifully between WiFi and cellular data, the camera takes excellent pictures with it's dual rear cameras and even the front facing selfie cam with basic built in beautify options work well.

The screen has an excellent built in coating that makes your finger slide over the glass very easy and it almost never builds up fingerprints, but when it does, just wiping it on my shirt cleans them off almost completely.

I have scores of apps on the phone and there are no conflicts with any of them, even lesser known apps work great as well as the bigger ones like Twitter, Skype, Facebook etc.

The battery life is very, very good as I rarely have to charge it more than once a day even using it for 7-10 hours a day with videos, movies, being on the phone for sometimes a couple of hours a day for work etc. It's 3385MAH battery works excellent.

The fingerprint scanner is BETTER than on my Samsung Galaxy, BLU and LG phone to, though the LG is second best. Just touching even a part of my finger to the sensor opens up the apps or unlocks the phone.

While the phone does NOT have an encrypted file system, which I really wish it did, it does come with a built in encrypted file safe for photos, documents, music or anything else you want to put in it.

It also has a built in app protector so that no app can be accessed without either the password or your fingerprint which again works within a third of a second every time. I like this as I'm very big on security.

So far I've gotten numerous updates from Blu including updating to Android 8.0 and many security updates.

I had an issue with certain apps and I contacted their online customer service via the chat feature. I got someone within 30 seconds and unlike most customer service who give you basic bs answers or stock answers, they understood the problem right away, which was not related to an issue with the phone but was a problem with the latest version of Google play store. Once they told me to remove it and download it again, the problem disappeared right away never to return.

Even though I have a good case in the phone, I've dropped the phone about 7 or 8 times and the phone still works great with no scratches on the screen at all.

I also like that the phone requires you to enter the password every three regardless for security reasons.

The phone call quality is absolutely beautiful and clear as it uses 4G for HD quality sound as good as my brothers $900 Galaxy 8. I've also NEVER had a dropped call even when being on conference calls of an hour or more and everyone sounds like they're right in the room with me. I also like that the phone has a built in Black list option to stop annoying spam calls which seems to be getting worse lately.

This is just an absolutely fantastic phone and several of my co workers have bought them after seeing my phone and hearing my praise of it. It's no wonder that Huawei sales have no SURPASSED APPLE to become the number twi phone seller in the world.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
I was limping along with my Nexus 6P and it finally decided enough was enough. I wanted an interim phone to get me through to the next Pixel release and decided on this since my Huawei 6P lasted me 2.5 years which is a lot for an android device. I am very impressed with this phone. For the price it is quite feature rich. The system is crazy smooth. The storage is 64GB which is twice that of my 6P. Memory stands strong at 4GB. This is great as long as management of it stays on point. The camera is good. Not great but it is quite usable for a device at this price point.

Pros:
- 64GB storage
- 4GB Ram
- 6" screen
- Works on Tmobile and AT&T LTE bands (no verizon or sprint)
- Crazy fast fingerprint reader in the CORRECT SPOT
- FM Radio and a headphone jack (common in Chinese phones)
- Good camera, but won't blow anyone away
- Dual SIM with great management tools
- Actual good battery life will get you through the day easy
- Slick all metal design, this is nice but also slippery. Luckily the phone comes with a free clear case. I bought the Spigen Honor 7X case though.
- $230???

Cons:
- Micro USB connection, better dig up your old cables
- No NFC, I use contactless payment a lot and this hurts
- No wireless charging, but this is a metal phone so eh
- EMUI skin is quite intrusive, I recommend Nova or Google Launcher on top, much better this way
- Only running Android 7.0, hopefully the Honor 7X beta program means Oreo will be coming to this device eventually, don't hold your breath though.
- This is a Chinese phone and these companies sometimes have questionable practices when using your personal data. Keep this in mind when buying lower end devices such as this. Probably doesn't matter though since your data is being harvested and sold by all phone manufacturers most likely. Might as well save a buck.

Overall I am very happy and impressed with this phone. Budget phones have come so far from the last time I had a lower end phone that I honestly did not expect this device to perform the way it is. This phone is easily worth the price. Micro USB being the biggest downfall of this device is understandable at this price point. This phone may get me to skip the new Pixel altogether! Buy this if you need something to hold you off until the next big thing OR if you are budget minded but still looking for a feature rich device.

**1 MONTH UPDATE**

This phone is still a great deal and I figured I would put a few more thoughts in this review since I have been using it for about a month. First the reason I am dropping this device to only 4 stars, battery management. This battery management is probably the opposite of what you think, it is TOO AGGRESSIVE. This phone has settings to kill what it considers "power intensive apps" when the device is locked and the screen is off. This option can be turned off which I have done, but it does not appear to be listening to me. The result of this is that I do not receive notifications for messages, smart things events, and many other things that I want to know as soon as they happen. Therefore I end up getting 3 or 4 notifications when I unlock the device. I have white listed all the apps that I want to continue running but the phone does not care. This is pretty annoying so I may end up rooting the device to remove EMUI.

The second annoyance I have found is that the phone does not allow you to set specific notification sounds per app. You get ONE notification noise for ALL your notifications. That sucks pretty hard. But, per my previous point, the phone doesn't tell you when you have notifications anyway so whatever I suppose.

The other notable point is that this device DID receive an Android Oreo update. This is great and unexpected on a budget device so I am happy to be on this later version of Android. Unfortunately, this isn't enough to save them from dropping a star.

Still a great device! Hopefully I can figure out a workaround for the battery optimization that kills your apps.

Label: Postif

Ulasan:
So far so good with this budget smartphone. A lot of people call this the King of the Budget Smartphones...I must agree.

I'm nitpicking, but here are a few suggestions that would make this phone perfect and probably $50-$75 more expensive, but I would still buy it.
1. Type C USB for charging
2. Dual Band Wifi (AC). Lacking this is a real bummer when a $40 Moto e4 at Walmart at least has dual band wifi
3. This phone only has LTE and would be better with LTE-A
4. fast/turbo charging
5. any type of water resistant rating
6. Optical Image Stabilization (OIS) But Google Photos (the android app version) does a pretty good job of fixing the shaky videos (after you shoot your shaky video)

Overall the phone is Really good and very well priced. And the battery lasts a Long Time! I am coming from a Moto X Pure (2015) edition and the Mate SE battery is 1000x better than my older Moto.

I also purchased the Honor View 10 to compare to the Huawei Mate SE. I know the View 10 has a better processor, more gigs of RAM (6 compared to 4) and double the internal storage, plus other features too...but when comparing them side to side, I don't notice a difference (i.e. speed or lagging) when using daily apps. When I use the Mate SE as a hotspot for my laptop, it is usually as fast as the View 10. I actually now prefer the fingerprint sensor on the back of the Mate SE better than the front of the Honor View 10. Using the sensor on the back seems easier and more comfortable than I ever thought it would.

So I don't think the View 10 is worth 2x the price of the Mate SE.

The Huawei Mate SE is a great budget phone that I am using as my daily phone now. I'm surprised at how much I like it, I did not think that would be the case. And it is not too expensive that I won't be upset replacing it within a year to 18 months with another newer budget phone. It will be interesting to see if Mate SE will still be as fast as it is now in 12 months.

Ulasan:
Ive had this phone for close to a month now and Im very happy with it. My previous 2 devices were Moto Gs, with the most recent being the G4. The G4 was a great phone that was only hampered by my dumb decision not to get the model with more RAM and Storage. I assumed I would get the G6 when it was released, but the announced specs were disappointing, (this will be the first G6 to not have a 6XX series snapdragon processor), and the price is higher than previous iterations. To be honest, the Moto E5 Plus is more attractive as a true budget phone.
The Huwaei Mate SE had solid reviews and great specs for the price, so I decided to buy it. I also considered waiting for the Nokia 6.1, but again, the specs (3GB RAM and 32GB on base model) dont campare to the Huwaei.
Pros:
Screen - I really like the 18X9 screen. The quality is great, with no color hues.
Fingerprint Scanner - I never understood the big deal about these things, but now I cant imagine living without it. It is lightning fast.
Memory & Storage - I think that anything with less than 4GB of RAM will not last more than a year without starting to significantly lag. With 4GB of RAM and 64GB of storage this phone should perform well for a while.
UI - The custom UI is actually pretty decent, and close to stock Android. This was actually the only thing made me consider not purchasing the phone, as Ive enjoyed the stock android on my Motos, and know that the Samsung UI is really annoying. This one is pretty straight forward.
OS - The Android 8.0 update came through today and resolved some issues. The touch sensitivity on the screen was an issue, but seems to be resolved now. Also, I had issues with pairing with my car that are now fixed. Nice!!
Camera - Im not a great judge of picture quality, and Im not going to say that it takes better pictures than my wifes iphone 7. It doesnt. It does, however, take much better photos than my G4 ever did. Thats all I really need. The camera could load faster, but oh well.
Processor - Plenty fast for my needs. In the ballpark of a 6XX series snapdragon, but it does underperform in nearly all benchmark tests. I dont play many games, but I downloaded PubG, just to see how it did, and it played nicely with no lag.
Case - Just want to point out that it comes with a pretty decent clear case. I didnt realize it when I ordered it. Consider that when you purchase the phone.
Cons:
OS - I miss the gesture controls for the camera and flashlight that I had on the Motos.
Network - GSM Only. Not necessarily a negative, but you should be aware of it. I bought a 12 month card for RedPocket and the service is pretty great.
No NFC - Ive never had this, but I imagine its like the FP Scanner. Once you have it, you probably dont want to go without it.
No Type C or turbo charging - For me, this is the only true negative. Fortunately, after nearly a decade of android ownership I have amassed roughly 3 million micro-USB cables, so Im never more than a few feet away from a convenient, albeit slow, charging solution.
Thats all the negatives I can think of right now. All in all, a fantastic phone for $250 (price when I bought it, $229 now). If youre a casual user like myself (no intense games, rarely watch videos), theres no reason to buy anything more expensive than this range of phone.

Ulasan:
My gosh, this little skinny phone has more power and speed than my high speed desktop from just 4 years ago! Plus I don't have to mess with windows hahahah. We bought two of them and set them both up at the same time... a simple chore but it took time because we first did the clone trick from our Huawei Honor 6X phones and then did the lengthy upgrade to EMUI 8.0. The cloning operation was spectacular... suddenly the new phone had EVERYTHING from our old phones, apps, contacts, pictures, videos, music, files... and then much better because faster and great full HD screen. Odd how it can have virtually the same outside dimensions, but the screen pictures are a half inch bigger! Great photos and videos, everything!

I do not have a single complaint or reservation about this phone yet, compared to any phone I've ever owned, and I've had some flagships. Easy operation, quick learning curve from the 6X, the cases we bought fit perfectly and securely.

This review will grow as I learn more about this phone, but to be able to get one this nice, this beautiful, this convenient and powerful for such a low price is just amazing. No wonder the competitors are creating fake news about it.

Ulasan:
I am replacing my old Samsung Note 3 which has well outlived its usefulness. This Huawei mate SE seemed somewhat of a compromise of speed and price so I decided to go with this phone. I did not realiize that it is so quick, responsive and easy to use. The screen is super responsive. The display is bright and clear. I would not be able to tell this from a top of the line phone and the price is amazing. Granted, my comparison is with a phone that has not been sold in years and barely works. But as a casual user this phone does everything one needs. There is no reason to spend more than three time the money on something that is equally outdated in just 12 months from now. Great phone with a huge display, thin profile an very good battery life. All the value and less fluff. Also the phone is not tied to the provider. Little bloatware..
Update: I have it now for a few weeks and use it every day off course. The phone is fantastic. The photos it takes are actually great. I like the fact that I can select the point of focus and the point to take the brightness of the picture. I can take decent interior real estate photos with it. Not 100 % as good as my DSLR with indirect flash but quite close. The lens is a good medium wide angle at around 28 mm (equivalent) focus length so you can cram a lot in it. But it takes pictures that don't look like they come from a phone. The bokeh function where the background becomes blurred and the subject is sharp works good and yield nice results. I did not expect the camera part to be so decent. I bought it with the thought in mind that I am settling for a bargain phone with a not so good camera. However, it allows me to do quite a bit more than with the old one. My camera bag stays at home quite a bit more. As a Realtor I can use this in a pinch and get great looking results that I can actually use without being embarrassed. (I hate when my colleagues use haphazard pictures that are done with a phone held upright where you can not see anything of the house) Compared to all the phones I had before, this is lightning fast and very responsive. I still love it. I completely love the price. Get this phone.
Update: I now have used it for about a week and love it even more. The battery life is incredible. When in a location with connected wifi the phone can last for about 3 days without a recharge. I presume the use of wireless data will cut down on the battery time a bit. But it is still plenty of time on the phone. This phone is incredible considering the really low price tag. Considering traveling abroad? It can take a second sim card and work both at the same time. Or have your work phone number and personal phone number routing to one device. I would not buy one of the flagship phones. There is truly no need since the Mate SE does everything one asks for an more. It even has a vault functions where you can protect your data and apps from unauthorized access. Good feature if you carry sensitive data or customer files on your phone. Also the ability to add storage with a sd card gives you affordable storage expansion. They even give you a cover with the phone so you don't need to get one right away. The thing I personally love it still has a headphone jack. Who ever complained about the presence of a headphone jack in a phone? Why are they gone in the most expensive phones? It does not make sense to not have one and deal with unreliable Bluetooth or cumbersome adapters. This phone makes sense in every way. There is no reason not to buy it. Did I mention that I love this phone? Best purchase I made in a long time.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
This could have been a fantastic cell phone:

PROS
1. Size - very light and thin
2. Clarity is great
3. Camera is great - good photo quality
4. Processor is fast
5. Price is great - I refuse to pay $1,000 for a cell phone

CONS
a. Major con - VERY FEW CUSTOMIZATION OPTIONS! One font and one font size? Fewer options than my Ascend Mate II
b. Related to a. above, TWO CHOICES FOR SCREEN BACKGROUND! The choices result in poor screen readability
c. BASICALLY NO INSTRUCTIONS SUPPLIED WITH THE PHONE, AND WEB INSTRUCTIONS ARE BASICALLY NON-EXISTENT

I am not sure if these problems exist with other Huawei cell phones. With a few minor tweaks, this could be the best cell phone on the planet based on cost and value.

Ulasan:
When I started working with computers in the 1980s, I never expected to walk around with 8 CPU cores, 64 GB of storage, and 4 MB of RAM in my pocket!

The price/performance ratio of this device is phenomenal, and it's a joy to use. The sound with Bluetooth and headphones is excellent (there is a headphone jack). There are few bloatware apps, and most can be removed.

The version of Android is not stock, but isn't annoying either. Huawei says the device will get Oreo in the future.

I am using this phone with T-Mobile in the USA and the call quality is good.

The phone can either take 2 SIMs, or 1 SIM and 1 microsd card. I installed my 128 GB microsd, so I have all of my music (ripped CDs) on the device.

I like that you can set up the phone to turn on with two taps to the screen. There is a step counter that displays on the lock screen which is useful to me.

Battery life seems to be pretty good. After fully charging the phone last night, and spending a lot of time installing software and configuring the phone, the next morning it's still at 60%. I even used the hotspot feature when my ISP had a brief outage, and I'm sure that uses a significant amount of power.

After charging to 100%, in the morning it was still at 97%.

The camera is quite good, but I still use a dedicated camera for photos that require a decent zoom.

May 13 Update:

I just received the OTR update for Android 8.0 (Oreo). The installation worked without a hitch, and Android 8.0 is running well.

Ulasan:
First impression, this is a thin and light phone. Screen is bright, performance is fast, not much junk loaded from the factory image. The setup gives you a way to move data and apps from another Android phone to your new phone.

Camera is good, phone has a fingerprint sensor. The OS image is not too far from a stock android version. The Sim is a nano site, and the tray for the Sim can hold either a second Sim or a micro SD card to expand the storage. This phone is both carrier unlocked, and comes with a US warranty.

Few negatives, does not have a knock code capability. Screen icons look pretty crappy in landscape orientation. Battery is sealed in and not replaceable similar to some other phones.

(Update) after using the phone for a few weeks: Battery life is great, my LG would be at 25% after a day of running around and moderate usage, the Mate SE is still at about 65% battery.

Other issues noted: The PIN code on the lock screen does not have a scramble option, which would be good to have again. A couple of little issues noted: 1) one time turning on the phone with the power button, the digital clock display did not show up. 2) In my email app, the screen started showing a blue color tinge. I restarted the phone and the issues have not reoccurred at this time.

Overall my impression is still that this is a very good phone for the price.

Works with T-Mo. No issues with getting 4G LTE connection. Talk and text working perfectly. First "unlocked" phone I've ever had and the transition couldn't have been any more easier. Just had to run to the T-Mo store to get a new nano sim card because my micro sim card from my old phone didn't fit (didn't even know there were different sim card sizes now).

Coming from a Samsung Galaxy Note 4 that was crapping out on my 5th battery after 3+ years, decided to go with this for the screen size at the price mainly. All the knocks on this phone are things and features that it doesn't have (that other phones have as a standard), but if you didn't need it or use it before then chances are you probably won't know it did not exist. It does everything that I wanted my Galaxy Note 4 to do, but faster with double the storage and a nicer screen. I'm already impressed with the battery life but I'm sure that will degrade over time. Still getting used to this version of Android and GUI but it looks neat.

My first new mobile device in over three years and I couldn't be anymore happier and impressed especially because of the price. Great bargain if you're looking to upgrade and catch up with the times, haha.

Ulasan:
Powerful phone, fast. The OS takes a whopping 14 gigs of space, leaving only 50 gigs free of the 64. The claim of 5.93 inch screen is only true if one includes the control panel. Actual viewable screen size (according to screen measuring software) is only 5.6". The screen does not have the look or feel of a true 6" screen. Does come with a case, which is a nice touch.

A shame it doesn't have induction charging. That would have been nice on a phone of this quality.

Was advertised as Android 7.0. When I turned it on almost first thing it did was update to a solid Android 8.0. Hurrah!

Annoying factor: despite the fact it has very accurate fingerprint-login recognition, every 3 days it requires entering the pin number. This can't be changed, it's not an option, it's hard-wired into the system. BAD HUNWEI. I suspect someone in design department trying to earn his wage with "new idea"... and missed the mark. It doesn't imrprove security, is an annoyance every 3 days, and NO CUSTOMER WANTS THIS, right? On that point alone I knock this down an entire star.

Watermark issue: the CAMERA app may come in default mode to stamp a Huawei logo blurb on every photo it takes. To fix this, go to settings and un-check the "Watermark" option. (Personally, I can't imagine why Huawei would believe any customer would want their company logo on our photos. What were they thinking?)

Major drawback: A customer reports turning on Wifi and Bluetooth at same time causes a major bottleneck. Something to be aware of if you regularly use a Bluetooth headset. Another star knockdown.

I am very impressed with its wifi speed. I wasn't aware until recently that different Android devices can have higher or lower wifi download speeds. This phone significantly out-performs every other Android device I've used in sheer speed of wifi downloads-- including my high-cost Android tablet.

Overall I'm quite pleased with this phone, with a couple of annoying exceptions. Yes, recommended.
Label: Postif

I have had the phone for about a week, and I love it. Everything is fast including the camera and fingerprint sensor. I like the quality of the photos. The phone is a little on the heavy side, but not too bad.

The one really disappointing thing for me is the battery life. I cannot get through a full day with even moderate use. I have put it on battery saver mode, made sure no apps are running in the background and made whatever other setting adjustments I could, but the battery life is still poor. I recharge once during the day for a while, and it is OK. However, I don't think I should have to do that. I am not sure if the battery is a general situation, or if I have just received a bad one.

Update 4/2/18: company emailed me about ways to increase battery life. It worked. The battery is now great, and so is this phone, probably the best I have ever owned! Dual sim is awesome. I live in Costa Rica, and need both Movistar and Kolbi for complete coverage.

If you are hesitant to buy this phone, DON'T BE! I think you will be very pleased with your purchase.

Ulasan:
This is the 9th day that I played with the phone and tried to make it work for me. But it could not work out.

I bought this phone out of curiosity and good reviews from Amazon. I was excited when I opened the box. I liked the hardware design of the product. But the SW is not there. Here are a couple of examples of bad bugs or design features that are troublesome for me.

1. The data transfer from my old Nexus to this phone needed to go through the cellular/hotspot data path instead of WiFi or other low cost means. This was the first surprise. Fortunately, I only picked up a couple of small items to transfer. Otherwise, I would have exhausted my data plan for the month without completing a 3rd of the transfer.

2. the icons in the app groups is way too small to see.

3. way too many meaningless settings for me to play with to get the phone to a point that I like it to be.

4. the camera is not able to zoom in in viewfinder mode (being referred to as "portrait mode" in the pop-up message when I tried to zoom).

5. There are a couple of Huawei related things such as "Huawei share" that I don't even want to try.

6. when I viewed pictures from my Google drive folder today, the pictures darkened themselves to a point that I can hardly see what's in the pictures. I found no way to change that behavior.

The item 6 above is the last straw that made me decide to return this product. I am not sure of what other surprises I will run into down the road. Enough and no more Huawei products. I am going back to Moto.
