Ulasan:
This is it, this is the phone you want to buy if your budget is less than $500. At half of that cost too. I always bought flagships, from Samsungs to HTC to Apple. I am switching to this phone from an iPhone X mainly because I wanted to sell it off before the next batch of iPhones were released, and also just because I missed Android. This phone is not a flagship and while you must keep in mind that this costs 4x less than most flagships, it does so well and I have little experience with budget phones that I can't help but compare it to them. I'm a week in and am so blown away by this phone that I figured it deserved a review. I do a lot of navigation for work, play Pokemon Go, and just normal social media from my phone.
Battery life - While it is not a two day battery life like some people claim, it is better than anything else I have used besides the Samsung Note devices. Normally I plug in when using Google Maps but decided against it just to test. After a full day at 50% brightness, waking up early and going to bed around 11, I was left with 10%. I had done around 3 hours of screen on navigation, around two hours of Pokemon Go, and around two hours of social media throughout the day. Very impressed. Should be noted that when I used the dual sim feature, the battery seemed to die a lot quicker and I was needing to charge by around 7.
Software - Running Huaweis own UI was the biggest concern of mine. I had almost went with a Nokia 6.1 because of the stock Android. It performed better than I could've imagined and I experience no slowdown at all, everything feels very snappy and I've only seen a couple lags on apps that seem to lag no matter the phone. Upgrade-able to Android 8.0 out of the box, time will tell if we get any more updates.
Design - Definitely nice feeling in the hand, I used the included case out of the box. Looks to be inspired my iPhone and while it is a good looking phone, I don't appreciate the branding on both the front and back. Although it is helpful as I had to check about 7 times to remember how to spell Huawei.
Display - A much nicer display then I thought would be possible on a device of this cost. Besides the blacks, I really can't tell a difference in this display and any from Apple or Samsung, definitely can't tell which is sharper but that may just be me. It does not get as bright as other phones, but I never use full brightness anyway.
Connectivity - Amazingly this was faster than both my iPhone X and my Galaxy S7. I am on the T-Mobile network and get around 50 mbps speed compared to the 37 on S7 and abysmal 13-20 on iPhone. GPS never has problems finding where I am and it reconnects very quickly. I don't use enough bluetooth to make a fair opinion but I will point out that some other reviews are correct. While on WiFi if you connect to a bluetooth device, my connection dropped by about 15 mbps. Not a big deal when it's 55 down to 40 in my case because it's still plenty fast but beware if you have a slower connection and use both a lot. I only use bluetooth in the car so it doesn't affect me. Oh this is a phone right? Call quality is decent. Nothing mind blowingly clear or really any difference from other decent phones. It also does not support 5ghz WiFi which is disappointing but not a deal breaker.
Camera - The part where most budget phones cut their corners. The camera is good. Better than most budget phones but not even close to any flagships. Low light isn't very good and it takes awhile to focus sometimes. Usually it gets the job done but this is probably the weakest point in the phone. Pictures can still look great provided you have proper lighting though. Front camera also gets the job done but a little washed out. I don't take selfies so again, not a deal breaker.
Value - Just buy it. I guarantee this phone will make you question why there are $1000+ smartphones. If you need a nicer camera on a phone I doubt you will find it on anything less than $600 though. It's a $230 phone that does 95% of everything phones 2,3,4x its cost will do. Plus you get a headphone jack, micro sd card or dual sim, there's also a case in the box. No headphones though. Extremely happy with this purchase and will update if anything changes.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
UPDATE 07-23-18: So it's taken a little bit, but I ran across a setting on the phone that I've not seen on other Android devices that could help a lot of folks out there especially when it comes to battery management. If you've done any sort of deep dive into this or other Huawei phones, you've undoubtedly come across their great battery life but also the fact that some apps don't behave as well or give out weird notifications. Let's keep this simple: Android operating systems let apps run after you open them until you make them stop running (by selecting all previously open apps and clearing them). EMUI skips all that nonsense by pretty much shutting everything down once you finish with it (or sometime soon thereafter). Great for battery, but bad for things like say something that relies on geofencing (yes Arlo, I'm talking about you). But there is a very simple workaround.

To get an app working and to have it continue to work (like the caller ID app HiYa) here's what you do. Go to Settings and then to Apps and Notifications. Select Apps. AT THE BOTTOM OF THE APP PAGE you'll see ANOTHER Settings icon. Click on it. Now select Special Access and then Exempt from Battery Optimization. Your final step: click were it says Allowed and select All Apps. Once that is done, find the app you want to exclude from battery optimization, select it, and then select Allow (may drain your battery more quickly).

Selecting a few of these shouldn't have an adverse affect on you battery, just don't go crazy and select everything. Good ones to have selected besides HiYa: Visual Voicemail, Dropbox, and Wear OS. Hope this helps!

UPDATE 05-18-18: About a week ago I started to get this error when checking on one of my apps: Google Play Services Are Updating. From what I've read, the problem seems to be confined to Huawei and Honor handsets (and one has to wonder if it's because of the recent update to EMUI 8.0 and Oreo 8.0). The fix is easy - navigate to Settings and then to Apps & Notifications, Apps again and then find Google Play Services. Once you tap on the app, go to Storage and then hit "Clear Cache". Once that is done, finish it off by going to "Manage Space" and then "Clear All Data." If you were getting the Google Play Services Are Updating error, it should be cleared. My error was coming through the Arlo app- others reported they were having problems with Google Maps and Uber (or any app that relies on Google Maps for location).

UPDATE 05-17-18: Phone recently received Oreo 8.0 and EMUI 8.0 update about a week ago. Phone seems a little faster and still pretty bulletproof. I mentioned Arlo app problems- turned out Arlo was having a little Android/server meltdown a few weeks back (that has straightened itself out). One tip: make sure under geo-fencing you have your home address typed into the address box (the app decided my phone wanted to be in Madagascar - if only...). Wireless adapter still works but will still do the annoying reset ping over and over randomly. Full screen problem seems to have disappeared with the update (or maybe I just finally set all of the apps to fs every time they asked). Still liking the phone and recommending it to anyone in the market for a new handset.

ORIGINAL POSTING: :If youre in the market for a new Android smartphone you have a multitude of choices. I recently started having problems with my Galaxy Note Edge (a one-time Samsung flagship) but given that the phone lasted way past its two-year mark, Id say I got my moneys worth.

The biggest factor in my decision making for getting the Huawei Mate Special Edition (SE) was price. Its hard to swallow paying upwards of $800 to $1,000 for a smartphone thats one drop away from becoming the worst thing to happen to you all week/month/year. On the other hand, after experimenting with lower-end budget phones (ZTE Maven and Moto G4), I learned that at least with Android, you do get what you pay for.

Im going to start with something a little different from most other reviews: apps I had to replace. Specifically, there were three stock apps that were tripping me up on the Huawei, because they wouldnt do certain things. I found free replacements for them on the Play Store and Ive had no problems since the switchovers.

 First the browser: Chrome on the Mate SE is slow and full of ads. I ditched it for (of all things) Samsungs Internet browser coupled with two extensions for ad blocking (Adblock Fast and Disconnect for Samsung Internet). Much faster and you have the advantage of a home screen of web shortcuts you can create inside the app.

 Next, the music player. For some odd reason, Huaweis music player doesnt read pre-made m3u files (these are files for playlists). You can make one on the phone, but if you have ones that were made on a computer, the phone wont recognize them. Solve it by installing another music player (I used Pi Music Player and it works just fine).

 As for the camera, the dual back facing cameras are pretty capable right out of the box (you will want to play with the photo and video settings to get high quality pictures). But there is one software/app problem that doesnt affect everyone but will affect some: in video mode, the camera wont recognize an external microphone. Most smartphones can handle a TRRS microphone (4 poles and three black rings) ; the stock camera app on this phone can't. Solution: download a different camera app. I used Open Camera; to get it to work, in video settings, set the microphone to use external mic when present and you should be good to go.

Now the good stuff.

Is the Huawei Mate SE a good substitute for a Galaxy Note Edge? Yes. Is it as perfect as the Note Edge was in its hey-day? Nope. Am I much happier with a new Huawei than a three-year old Samsung? Definitely.

So lets start with whats missing.

Theres no NFC, no 5G wi-fi, no removable battery and of course, no S-Pen. The Mate SE also has a bottom firing speaker that while loud, is kind of weird the first few times you listen to it. Screen resolution on the Mate SE is not as bright and crisp as the Note Edges Super AMOLED display (but after a few days youll get used to it).

What will you NOT get with the Mate SE that youll get on other smartphones (some priced the same, some more expensive)?

 No USB-C- Not a deal breaker for me b/c I have a ton of Micro USB chargers and cables lying around (so its actually a plus right now).

 No Android 8.0 Oreo- The Mate SE ships with Android 7.0 (Nougat) but since the Mate SEs sister phone the Honor 7x is now going through beta testing with 8.0, Oreo is probably in the Mates very near future.

So what is there to like?

 Battery life. I run the same exact apps (plus the three substitutes I mentioned) on my Huawei as I did on the Galaxy Note Edge. At the end of the day, the Edge was at about 15% but the Mate SE is at about 50%. The Mate SE has a 3340mAh battery; the Note Edge a 3000mAh battery. Size-wise, its not a big difference, but the phone, the processor, and the 7.0 OS versus the 6.0 OS on the Note is obviously much more efficient. Advantage Huawei.

 The fingerprint sensor. THIS THING WILL BLOW YOUR MIND. Ive used a fingerprint sensor before, but I found it finicky and slow. Not so here: the Mate SEs sensor is super, super, SUPER fast. Touch it, and youre in.

 Landscape mode: This is odd- on my Samsung Galaxy Note Edge I could never get the phone to do a decent landscape mode on the home pages. Inside an app, no problem, but on the home screens, it never worked. This phone does landscape on all pages. Its a little thing, but after missing it for so long, its kind of cool.

Cool Stuff Ive not seen before since my last new smartphone three years ago:

 IP67 dust or water resistance (originally I didn't think it had it, but apparently it's on the spec sheet).

 Screenshot scroll. Youve probably done a screenshot before, but what happens when you want to get an entire page as a screenshot that is longer than what you can see on the screen? Screenshot scroll takes care of that: its built-in software that will copy an entire page not just what is displayed on the phone (find it in drop down navigation menu). A regular screenshot is just a tap on the navigation button as well (instead of remembering a combo of volume up and power keys).

 Speaking of the drop down navigation menu, Huawei gives you the ability to add a fourth button for that navigation menu at the bottom of your display. You can program the fingerprint sensor to perform a task by sliding your finger across the sensor (like say opening the camera), blocked numbers can be based on keywords and contacts, and Huawei has a virus scanner baked into the phone under the phone manager app.

 Other goodies: you can encrypt photos and videos as well as lock certain apps so that you (and your fingerprint and nobody else) can use the app. Finally, theres App Twin- the ability to log into the same app using two different accounts at the same time. two different logins on the same app at the same time.

My last comments: troubleshooting some apps and things.

 If you happen to use Waze with Android Auto, youre going to have problems with the Mate SE the first time you try it. The fix: go to settings, go to apps, select Android Auto, delete all data including the cache, start Android Auto BEFORE you connect it to the car and go through the permissions. Once done, connect it to the car and you should be good to go. Dont ask, all I know is it worked for me.

 I still havent properly figured out why the phone and Wear OS (for smartwatches) isnt perfect (I had to reboot and start over several times to get watch faces to download.

 If you miss wireless Qi charging from your old phone (or you want to add it to this one), buy a wireless adapter. I modified my old Note Edge to do wireless charging using an internal wirless pad; I did the same with the Mate SE using one that plugs into the bottom of the phone (search for a "narrow side up" Nillkin Magic Tag Qi Wireless Charger). It's about 12 bucks- worth the investment. The only drawback with mine: the Huawei Mate SE "cycles" through a bunch of charges. What I mean by cycle is it will charge, the screen will light up, and the phone will beep. That's normal when you start to charge, but it kept doing this over and over again about every 30 seconds or up to 2 minutes or so between cycles. Strangely sometimes it does it, sometimes it doesn't. I finally just loaded an old schedule setter app that turns the ringtone to zero each night and back to 100 in the AM in place of Do Not Disturb.

Ill finish with this: the dumbest thing about this phone (and the nicest!) is the 18x9 display. On most apps it works perfectly fine. On some, a dialogue box pops up asking if you want to go full screen. My answer is always yes and when I hit it, it makes you sometimes start all over again. Huawei- please fix this! Its the one annoying aspect of your phone that there doesnt seem to be a quick fix for.

Conclusion: if you need a new phone, buy this one. It comes with lots of memory (64GB built in) and lots of operating RAM (4GB). You can pop in a big SD Card (I have a 128GB) or another SIM if you want to go dual-SIM. Is it going to be as good as a flagship phone? No. But are you getting $600-$700 more umph in a Note 8, S9, iPhone 8 or iPhone X than you would in a Mate SE? Thats for you to decide.

# # #

Ulasan:
This review is way overdue, however I wanted to give myself time to use the phone and get used to its features so I have good information regarding its good qualities and bad ones as well. Fist of oll i am coming from the flagship world of LG and OnePlus phones. I've had the OnePlus One, X, and OP2. Also from the LG Family i've had all of the G Series phones from the G2 all the way through the G6 as well as all V-series phones, V10 and V20, .except the V30. In actuality it was the Huawei Mate SE that Drew me away from the V30 Purchase that I was about to make.The Good/Excellent Qualities of this phone. Actually there is nothing good about this phone.... The things that you like about this phone, are GREAT!!!!
Battery Life: I will go through 1complete day of heavy use (heavy video 3hrs and audio 2hrs streaming) plus regular internet and app (instagram and email) use. no gaming, and still have 15 - 20% battery life by the time i'm going to bed. So Battery life for me is outstanding and it does come with a quick charge feature as long as you use a qualcomm or compatible quick charge device.
Screen Resolution_ Outstanding. Pictures are crisp and colorful and the the stock UI comes with enough options to adjust color and hue to your liking. Also direct sunlight viewing is outstanding with no visible loss in color or shading. Love it!
Processing Speed without a doubt is excellent. Just as fast as any Flagship phone i've ever used. I multi task quite a bit (also come s with a split screen mode which i use frequently to fact check or look up items that I watch on youtube or shopping) and this phone handles everything that I do and more.
WIFI and Bluetooth - comes with an outstanding wifi radio which gets excellent reception from wifi transmitters that you may have problems with on other devices. Also the Bluetooth radio is excellent as well. more of a typical experience but non problematic as most Bluetooth setups are.
Form Factor: its lightweight and thin. very similar to an iphone 7+ or maybe a samsung glaxy 8+
finger print reader: Outstanding. quicker than an LG phone by noticeable lengths. and very reliable.

the not so great or just good::
bluetooth connectivity. I was having difficulties connecting the bluetooth after 3 days of continuous use withouth shutting the phone off. Ive found that shutting the phone off every 2 days alleviates the problem. however now Ive set the phone sho shut off and turn back on at 545-550 in the morning and now i don't even have to touch the phone. my bluetooth now connects flawlessly evry time i enable it.
The camera is good. i can take good quality pics with this phone in normal to medium/low light levels. I take hundreds of photos weekly and i am not disappointed in its capabilities. i've had better but for what you get with this phone, it heavily outweighs the camera inabilities
Lack of USB C..... Okay, this was a big one for me. as all of my newer phones from OnePlus2 to my LG G6 and V20 have had USB type C. It was hard switching back to micro usb and i notice the micro chargers are more susceptible to the ends bending where USB type C are more rigid. But for 239 dollars, it was worth the trade off but to be honest its a livable condition considering the high quality of the phone and the price.

In closing this phone dwarfs the LG G6 and V20 in functionality (ie.UI, and performance) and comes with a dual sim Tray, one of which can be used for expandable memory up to 256GB. but with 4GB of RAM, 64GB of available memory, you probably won't need it.,

Thats it! Honestly, the phone is amazing overall and i Highly recommend buying the Mate SE over the 7X as the added memory and processing speed are worth the extra 30-40 dollars you'll spend.on the phone. As long as Huawei keeps making high quality phones in this price range, i don't ever think i'll buy another 500-1000 dollar phone every again!.

Ulasan: Very good value smartphone considering it's relatively low price point. My only complaints are that the camera quality is not as nice as my old MotoX, the external speakers leave a lot to be desired (volume is very low even when set on max, especially if you have a phone case), and the fingerprint sensor is a bit finicky sometimes. The phone also comes with a lot of bloatware apps, which I disabled upon setting up. The battery life is amazing compared to my old MotoX though. I can use it all day browsing the internet and it will still have plenty of power at the end of the day. I also snowboard in the winter and even in single digits temperatures the phone stays on and holds its charge. Just make sure you check with your phone carrier if this phone is compatible first. This model works perfectly on the AT&T network. However it is not fully compatible with T-Mobile - as per their tech Dept, the Mate SE is 100% compatible on the data network, but only 50% compatible on the calls/texts, so that is something you will want to keep in mind.

Ulasan: Great mid range smartphone with 64 gb of internal memory and 4 GB of RAM. The phone is well built, and has a solid feel to it. The camera, while not on par with the highest end Apple or Samsung Galaxy phones, is great in good light situations. I normally use the phone heavily, with streaming satellite radio at work while surfing the web and maybe playing a game. The ram in this thing means that everything runs smoothly. I have not had one problem with this phone. In fact, I bought a second one for my wife and she loves hers also. Two of these phones cost less than one of the even last generation Iphones or galaxies. Octa core processor, 64 GB of memory, 4 GB of ram, all at a great price.

I am using this on the metro pcs network. I am upgrading from the ZTE Zmax Pro and have to say this phone is a massive upgrade. There is nothing you can complain about here:

+Bright crisp display. 24bit, 1080p,5.93in,ips,18:9,gorilla glass. Awesome colors with deep inky blacks.
+Fast Processor: 2.3ghz octa-core processor
+Memory: Whopping 4gb Ram+64gb onboard storage! Micro sd expandable up to 256gb
+Camera: 8MP front camera combined with a dual 16MP rear. Takes quick very clean photos
+Software: Updated to Android Oreo. Stock phone has minimal bloatware. Useful preinstalled apps
+Unlocked: GSM network
Bottom line if this phone had Apple or Samsung pained on the front the price would be $499 minimum. I can't say enough how much value this phone offers. Fantastic phone!

It's a pretty buggy phone. Overall it's okay for the price but I wouldn't compare it to any flagship phones. I had HTC M8 before for a very long time and it served me well. In some ways it still beats this Huawei SE.

Things that stand out to me after a couple of months are: camera quality is lacking; vibrate mode is barely noticeable and I miss a lot of calls because I can't feel it buzzing; speakers are okay and it's not as loud as my old phone, sometimes it's hard to hear people even on max; no extra storage slot; bluetooth doesn't work with Apple products; Huawei suit is not available in Apple store so I don't even know how to transfer files at this point, useless; virtual keyboard could be better; tap to zoom works in a weird way, especially in games; some other things I can't think of right now.

It's an okay phone, like it's good but it's okay. It's a 3 star phone that is nothing special or mindblowing. It's buggy and while I am writing this review, the phone asked me to pair my Apple... when I turned off bluetooth on the phone and my Mac 5 minutes ago. It's the little things like that...

Ulasan:
Been using this awesome phone now for a week. I will list the pro's and con's of the phone.
Pros:
64 GB of internal storage. That is a ton of space for apps you can put on the phone. Pictures and videos also if you don't have a microSD card. Love it.
MicroSD card slot. I put in my MicroSD card and for the first time a smart phone that didn't ask to reformat the card and lose all your pictures. That is pretty awesome.
Kirin 659 CPU is fast! Octa Core CPU running 4 cores at 2.36 GHZ and 4 Cores at 1.7 GHZ. Every app opens really fast.
4 GB of RAM. I have had up to 20+ apps open at the same time and still had 2 GB free of RAM. No slow down with many apps open with more RAM to spare to open up a bunch more apps.
Phone running Nougat 7 Android OS and I heard that Oreo 8 Android will be rolling out to the phone next month in May. That was a big selling point to me to get the latest Android. When I set up my phone it had a update for EMUI and also updated to the latest security updates released by Google Android.
Antivirus protection already on the phone out of the box. Avast security is running on the phone! Pretty good antivirus program and didn't have to pay for the antivirus program. Always a plus. I found this by looking through all the settings on the phone.
The one speaker sounds pretty good while on the speaker phone or listening to music. Wish it had 2 speakers.
I easily connected to my Bluetooth Headset and Bluetooth on my car stereo which sounds really good.
The Camera has alot of settings you can change and takes pretty good pictures.
For $229 this phone works great.
Cons:
The only con I find in this phone is wish the battery was bigger. At least a 4000 MAH battery. However I browse the web, check work and personal email, Facebook, google +, listen to Pandora internet radio all day, text, make phone calls, access other apps and still have some battery life at the end of the night before I go to bed. I have always felt that smartphone batteries could be better/bigger but this battery on this phone does its job.

Ulasan: Why spend $1000 on a phone when this $230 phone does most of what you need? The display is edge to edge (left to right), the body is unibody aluminum, the fit and finish is great, the fingerprint reader is amazingly fast, and the performance is really fast. They also give you a free clear case that fits well. I have the Huawei noise canceling earbuds, but they don't charge via the phone headphone jack, like it does on older Huawei phones. I am not a power user of a phone, but I am impressed with the Huawei quality/performance for the price. Setup is easy, you run a Huawei cloning app on your old phone, and it transfers data and apps to the new phone vis Bluetooth. Compared to aluminum iPhone, the antenna lines on the back look much nicer, and the blend into the case much better.

Ulasan:
I've had the phone for several months and so far it has been great. I'm using a Samsung Fast charger which I feel has made the charging faster compared to the standard charger. The phone is a little larger than what I'd like but the screen real estate is fantastic! The screen is durable but I would recommend a screen protector.

This phone isn't like the flagship phones in which some features you are used to may not work as well on this phone, although they are being updated often. One thing is if you have more than 1 bluetooth device connected it cannot figure out which one to use. This is being fixed with Android Oreo which is being pushed in the next month.

If you're looking for accessories, look for Honor 7x instead of the Huawei Mate SE. This will make things much easier and at times cheaper too. They are the same phone just rebranded for the US markets for some reason.

I've refereed this phone to others and I will not be buying a $800 phone again.

I was surprised by the specs given the price and decided to give it a go. So glad I did! I'm in my 60s and found it very easy to transfer my old phone. G-mail didn't work at first but once all the Google updates were complete, it was perfect. The display is bright, audio clear and the font size is customizable. Pictures are clear and crisp. Most of all, I love that the phone is so light and easy to hold. I usually have 30 percent battery left at the end of the day. I've always had an Android phone and this tops every one of them. Everything about this phone is fast and smooth. Highly recommend!

If you have read my reviews you know that I don't immediately review a new phone, I like to get a good feel for it before I post my opinions for the world.

The Good: Great Phone, Good Build Quality, Big Clear Screen, Good Battery Life, Almost stock Android OS, Plenty of Ram, Fast Enough Processor, and Plenty of Space (plus you can add a MicroSD card for more).

The Neutral: Huawei has been in the news quite a bit recently for all sorts negative things, unless you work in government I wouldn't let that impact your opinion, this is a solid phone.

The Bad: System updates have bricked my phone twice. Once was right after I got the phone (annoying but okay) the second time was last night. Its easy enough to boot into recovery and wipe the phone to get it back up and running (I keep most of my data on micro SD card so data loss isn't an issue) but setting all of my apps back up and getting everything back the way I want it is time consuming. So -2 stars and Im returning it.

Ulasan:
This phone is fast, comes with plenty of builtin storage, and fingerprint reader is a huge plus but overall I would rate it three stars only as I find it not quite up to par with 3 other awesome Huawei phones I have had in the past. Huawei seems to have cut corners on this one. Now on, I'll have to think twice or may be thrice if I should continue to go with Huawei on my next upgrade. At least I'll be sure to check out reviews thoroughly. Read below to know why.

The most annoying thing about this phone is the touch quality. Clearly touch screen has flakiness near edges. For example, if you write something using the builtin keyboard (I think it is called g-board) you will find that most of the taps to "backspace" key would not work. Similarly some other keys as well, such as letter P. The touch quality seems to improve little bit after taking Android 8.x upgrade, and then followed by some system app upgrades (specially related to g-board app) via Google Play, but some flakiness still persists. Well, Huawei may claim that this is not normal and could be an isolated problem with my phone unit only, but hey I own two of these phones (one for me, and one for wife) and both have this same *exact* issue. I even replaced one, and that one also had the same issue. So I know this is a real problem and not isolated one.

Dual Sim is a false advertisement. Although you can have two nano sims installed, but only one of them can be enabled at a time. The one that is enabled will show carrier name, while the other sim would show "Emergency calls only". Effectively, you cannot receive calls / sms on both SIMs at a time. Another setback.

Networked apps feature does not work correctly. If I set an app to not work on Mobile Data connection, it would not work on Wifi as well even though it is allowed on Wifi. I typically do not like to allow apps such as WhatsApp to use mobile data connectivity, but due to this bug I cannot keep such apps from using mobile data. This bug also seems to affect System Apps. If Google Play is disallowed over Mobile Data, it would not work on Wifi as well. Very annoying.

Overall three stars. I was expecting better.
Label: Postif

Ulasan:
First let me say that I have been using cell phones for the last 2.5 decades and have watched them progress to where they are today.
Over the years, out of a the blue companies (we all know who they are) starting producing phones at MUCH higher price levels and the public bought them which generated MASSIVE profits for those companies.. After all they are selling you phones that cost less then $150 to make for $700 + dollars to you.
I have never been one of those people, I always looked for value however I have A LOT of experience with expensive Apple and Android phones as besides my personal phone (and those in my family) my workplace supplied me with those expensive phones. Quite honestly, except for trying to "show off" I never really liked them.

Anyway it allows me to make direct comparisons to our less expensive personal phones and I never knew what the big deal was by owning the expensive ones, except to brag to friends about the most expensive phones someone bought.. To me that is a waste of money and I always knew those people who had those expensive phones never really "bought" them and only had them because they made monthly payments, anyone can do that.

Ok on tho the Huawei, our family has 3 cheaper versions on ATT service called the Elate, beautiful phone, cost us $70 each.
I was so impressed with them, I started to look into other offerings from Huawei and read up on the Huawei Mate SE.
I was pleasantly surprised at how well the Huawei phones review at ALL price levels. So I decided to buy myself the a New Huawei Mate SE as a sort of after Christmas present from my wife.

All I can say is WOW, this phone is AMAZING. Fit, finish, construction, beautiful refined feeling that you get with high end phones, yet this one is only around $200. NOT $1000 dollars.
It does everything any phone costing 4 times its price can do and do it with really good battery life.
Now lets get real, of course if your some super gamer/power user who needs a super high speed processor for some reason of course you will want the latest greatest processor at MUCH higher cost and much higher profit for the phone company.
For the average to above average American, they would never notice a difference, same with he camera, great camera, better then expected, is it as good as a $1000 phone? I can not answer that because when I take REALLY serious photos I use a Nikon digital SLR camera. I can tell you, Im not sure which is better, the camera in my work Iphone or this phone, so that is saying a lot.

Anyway, if you are someone who is considering this phone, I can honestly tell you, you cant go wrong. Just do it, I cant see how ANYONE can be disappointed and I see my wife now, holding it in her hand and it wont be long until she retires her other Huawei for another Mate SE. :o)

Ulasan: This phone has exceeded my expectations so far. I've only had it for a couple weeks this far but in this short time I have to say this device is amazing for the price. It's still a pretty good for a budget phone and will still take pretty good quality pictures. The only real complaint I have is the feedback from the audio jack when connecting to my car's auxillary port. Other than that I have no complaints. The fingerprint scanner is super quick and it's packed with plenty of feature overall. There's no wifi calling, is usb, 5 ghz wifi chip or nfc chip but these are all extra feature that I would expect from a much more expensive phone and nothing that j need by any means. Best $220 I've spent in a while!

Ulasan:
Pros:
- Inexpensive
- Free silicone case
- Headphone jack
- Fingerprint scanner
- Dual Sim capability
- Aluminum body
- 4GB of RAM
- 64GB of internal storage
- Support Micro SD up to 256GB
- Excellent battery life
- Hardly overheat
- Acceptable performance/camera quality

Cons:
- No 5GHZ (802.11ac) WIFI
- Outdated Bluetooth 4.1 standard
- Micro USB
- No NFC
- Not waterproof
- CAT 4 LTE with no carrier aggregation support
- Doesn't support T-Mobile LTE band 66/71
- No OIS/EIS
- OEM bloatware

Overall the Mate SE offers a ton of great things at an affordable price, it does come with compromises that can't be overlooked. At the end of the day, you get what you pay for.

This is essentially an upgraded Honor 7X, and the extra $30-$50 difference in price for extra RAM and double the storage was definitely worth it. Pulled the trigger and bought two Mate SE's, one for me and my wife. The research did not disappoint, we absolutely love these phones, I got the black version, she got the gold. Ulasan:
After using Apple for several year, then switching to Samsung, the bottom line is that I was getting tired of paying over $800 for a cell phone. This is a great phone for the money, but if you use Bluetooth often, you might want to consider something else. I use this Bluetooth with headphones and 3 different cars. The main problems are in the cars. Apps such as Audible regularly skip, slow down, speed up, or just stop. Podcasts do the same thing. I can't even get it to recognize my home stereo to pair it. Even with the WIFI turned off, the Bluetooth is spotty.

The pictures appear good, but are pretty bad in high contrast shots. I took a picture of my daughter's soccer team on a bright sunny day (the best conditions in terms of camera light) and the pictures look like a painting when you zoom in at all. The image just looks way too digitized. For lower contrast and lower light shots, the pictures are great. But high contrast, bright pictures tend to look almost like a bad oil painting when zoomed in.

Update 12/19/18 - After 6 months of use, I find that I am constantly cursing at this phone because of the Bluetooth. It won't go 15 minutes on an audiobook without freezing, skipping, or speeding up. When I'm on a call in the car, it will constantly switch from handset to bluetooth, back to handset, then to bluetooth. This renders is useless for hands free calls. I spend a lot of time in the car and depend on blutooth, so I'm likely going to chalk this one up as a loss and go back to Samsung. It just isn't worth the frustration.

Ulasan:
*updated to reflect over 7 months of usage*

Pros:
-large storage
-large screen with great image (until con- screen burn chances!)
-long battery life
-many camera options (*does not mean great results)
-Dual Sim (I don't use but for those who do...)

Cons:
-screenburn after about 8 months
-bloatware
-no 5g Wi-Fi connectivity (other budget phones have this so I think it's a fair comparison)
-sound (tiny speaker--alarms can be a challenge to hear!)
-Bluetooth (constant interruptions and need to reconnect after extended periods of time)
-incompatible with Android Auto
-many apps require you to perform special go arounds for them to work (pill reminder, TrueCaller to name a few)
-camera software takes awkward selfies (weird proportions, unclear)
-no fast charge abilities

Summary:
I purchased this to replace my Moto. I was most hoping for at least a similar experience however while there are some great aspects (screen, battery life) I found there to be many things surprisingly lacking.

But first let me start with the good so this review isn't all gloom! The battery life is amazing, and I do love the screen size and quality. Transferring files was an easy, though long, process (took about 4 hours despite the 2 hour estimated time) to help make my phone switch rather seemless. The phone is responsive and I'm enjoying the large memory--both ROM and RAM.

*note that this phone uses Nano Sim cards so you will possibly need to change your Sim card out if use another size*

Within the first day I was disappointed at the amount of bloatware. Besides some huawei apps you can't remove there are also some Android apps you are stuck with (Gmail being an example). I also found the speaker quality to be highly disappointing. Being on the bottom edge of the phone the sound is rather quiet and doesn't sound as clear as other phones.

Within the first week the disappointments continued. The selfie camera is not really useful--most always blurry and at times the aspect ratio would leave photos distorted. No 5G WiFi I can live with, but I miss having the option to connect to another network. Certain apps are incompatible with Huawei devices and others require you to go in to your settings and follow a series of steps just to get important notifications to work (specifically my pill reminder app, Medisafe, cannot remind me of pills automatically; TrueCaller cannot scan phone calls actively without special changes to settings). Also I have found the alarm app to be unreliable due to the poor, low speaker quality I've have missed several of the-something I have not had a problem with when using other devices.

And within a month of use I was also bummed to find that Android Auto does not work with this-or most all Huawei - phone. Using Bluetooth I had to become used to songs cutting out sporadically for a few seconds and after about 40+ minutes of use the signal would stop completely requiring a reset of Bluetooth on the device.

After 7 months Bluetooth continues to be a disappointment with increases in not connecting to other devices (especially car). Then I was surprised to find it get screen burn- I didn't realize that was still a thing but apparently so. Tried several apps that were to help. Didn't seem to quite work, perhaps over time it'll get better--but the way things are going with this phone it'll probably get worse.

Overall while at first the price point was attractive, as more aspects disappointed me I have come to realize this switch was not a very good one. Can I live with it? I can, and need to, but with other budget phones having many of these features I think this will be the first, and last, huawei phone I purchase. There are definitely better options in this price range out there if you're someone who uses a phone beyond battery life and general practical use.
Label: Negatif

Ulasan:
This is our initial take on this purchase after just 1 day, but the other half is extremely happy. The main features for him are: (1) more RAM and storage; (2) faster processor; (3) better screen resolution; (4) easy setup; and (5) auto-detection of resources like WiFi and SD card. The first 3 were a given with this phone vs his OnePlus One. The easy setup was a bit impressive though... as always, it offers to install any apps that your Google account had listed as installed... but it also has an option to clone your data from your old Android phone. To our surprise, after all was installed and it updated to Android 8.0 (Oreo), we tried the camera app... and it notified us that it had already directed photo saves (except burst-mode) to the SD card... the music app automatically found the music on the card without any prompting. The phone also asks to detect when you are home so that it can turn on the WIFI and connect to your home network automagically. OK... cool enough for him.
I wanted him to have this phone for the first 3 reasons and for better coverage, as this phone supports 4 of TMobileUSA's LTE bands (B2, B4, B5, and B12)... though they have recently introduced a 5th band. It also has EMUI 8.0 which are the HuaWei Android interface add-ons which typically include extra battery options and the ability to control certain app permissions in the phone. The build quality seems really good... similar to my Moto G5... yet it looks much better and it feels much more sleek.
Also, the dual rear camera is quite the surprise... it is quite good at taking pictures and it seems to have lots of other options in the HuaWei app... though we will explore other from the GPstore. The larger battery might have been a plus, but until he uses it more I am thinking that the extra RAM, bigger screen and processing power will negate that extra battery life at least a bit...
So far, this is one of the best phones I have ever seen in this price range... USD229 well spent!

Notes: (1) there is now enough space to install all of those pesky apps right on the phone (no SD necessary) leaving the SD for music and pictures if you install one; (2) starting and switching apps are brilliantly quick tasks with the octa-core processor backing the 4G RAM; (3) the screen is large and bright and responsive with loads of pixels (2160x1080) and great for watching things in HD as well...
Label: Postif
